**Self-Help Books**  
Diane Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a manuscript by an unknown psychologist, Dr. John Gray. "I knew it would be a bestseller," she says, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Diane started her own company. Dr. Gray's book about improving communication between men and women is very popular and represents a growing self-help industry in America. This industry tries to meet people's desires for self-improvement, but it also creates new desires and supports the publishing industry in New York. In Britain, many self-help books are published, but many more are rejected because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are now looking for the next big hit, and they focus more on how marketable a book is rather than its writing style. Diane says, "If someone has a catchy title, that's a big part of the success. It helps reach people."

**Autobiographies**  
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement that they will tell the truth. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too shameful or not important enough. Sometimes, they might invent stories that express their truth better than just sticking to the facts. An autobiographer might call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe they are reading true events, even if the story is mostly fiction. This can happen without any intention to deceive.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**  
Experts say that detective stories became popular because they reflect the conflicts of society in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. In these stories, crime symbolizes human desires like greed or lust, and solving the crime helps restore order in society. However, in Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. The detective understands the criminal, and they share a strange connection. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. His job is complicated by his feelings of guilt and his desire for justice.

**Science Writing**  
Stephen Jay Gould is one of the best science writers today. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. He said he couldn’t write well in such a fancy place because understanding the culture is important for a writer. Science is its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. If you don’t know the community and its rules, you will struggle. Gould believes in never writing down to the reader. "You can make the language simpler, but don’t change the ideas," he says. "If readers feel you are talking down to them, they will lose interest."

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, the air feels very cold. To handle this summer's high temperatures, the gym has used a lot of air-conditioning. Sometimes, it feels like being in the Arctic. This shows how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It is now a common part of our work and leisure, showing how we can control the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas may seem simple, but they can make a big difference and reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are becoming more interested in sundials, which are tools that tell time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, sundials were important for keeping time accurately. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, believes people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago, where serious-looking older women showed how to paint delicate flowers on teacups. It was fascinating to watch them, as each brushstroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners have natural talent? However, the atmosphere in the class was friendly and fun. Everyone was there to enjoy themselves, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

**The Wrong Country**

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport, twelve nights in Venice, the beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that the other travelers were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation, or that the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks, and then more drinks. 

When they landed, a stout woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on. Stay together now." There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith realized that this was clearly an unexpected stop. It was close to midnight, and tired from traveling, they did not question the beds they were offered. But the next morning, when they found out they would be staying there for their entire holiday, they became worried.

"We have the lake and the water birds," the receptionist said with a smile. "And we can take a boat to Interlaken." 

Keith calmly told the man, "There has been a mistake. We were supposed to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." 

"I do not know that name, sir. This is Switzerland," the receptionist replied. 

"A coach is supposed to take us on. An official said so on the plane," Keith insisted. 

"Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you have changed your minds—" 

"We haven't changed our minds. There has been a mistake." The receptionist shook his head, saying he did not know about any mistake. 

Dawne then said, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. 

"Is there a problem?" a woman said, smiling at Keith. She was the stout woman he had seen at Gatwick. 

"My name is Franks," she said. "I'm married to the man with the bad leg." 

"Are you in charge, Mrs. Franks?" Dawne asked. "We are in the wrong hotel." 

Again, Dawne mentioned the travel agency and described the bald clerk. Keith interrupted, "It seems we got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl and left it to her." 

"We should have known when they weren't from Dover," Dawne added. "We heard them talking about Darlington." 

Keith was impatient and wanted to speak. "We noticed you at Gatwick. We knew you were in charge." 

"I counted you, although you probably didn't see me," Mrs. Franks replied. "Let me explain. Your-Kind-of-Holiday sends clients to many places, with different holidays at different prices. There are villa holidays for young people, treks to Turkey, and treks for singles to the Himalayas." 

"What I am trying to say is that all tickets and labels look similar, yellow with two red bands," Mrs. Franks laughed. "If you followed others with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up in a wildlife park! But that couldn't happen." 

"We're not supposed to be in Switzerland," Keith insisted. 

"Let's see," Mrs. Franks said unexpectedly and walked away, leaving them standing there. The receptionist was no longer at the desk, and they could hear typing. 

"She seems kind," Dawne whispered. Keith was not listening. He tried to remember everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and then the girl leading them to the plane. 

"Nice to have some young people along," an elderly man said. "Nottage is the name." His wife was with him, and they both looked very old. They said they had the best night's sleep because of the lakeside air. 

"That's nice," Dawne said. Keith walked out of the reception area, and Dawne followed him. Outside the hotel, they did not say that there was an irony in what had happened. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they had ended up on a package tour with older people when they wanted to escape the needs of the elderly. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to convince him to join them.

**Text: 'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON'**

American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a model for good management. Eluned Price reports.

Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal described Shackleton as "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is an exaggeration. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many biographies and stories about Shackleton's voyage on the Endurance are being published, and the American Museum of Natural History is preparing a big exhibition. Columbia Tristar is also making a film about his life.

Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his leadership and communication skills and often refer to his actions as lessons for modern business. Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become an example for management consultants. Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for years. His firm focuses on communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises.

MacGregor explains that even if a company handles a crisis well, poor communication can still cause problems. He believes Shackleton is a great model for management because he had strong values and was at his best when his team had a lot to lose, including their lives. One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This choice showed his commitment to the safety of his men.

In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary when his ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually sank. When the ship went down, Shackleton told his men, "We should all eventually reach safety if you do your best and trust me." His leadership was clear from the accounts kept by his men; he was always in control.

MacGregor notes that Shackleton planned carefully, kept his men informed, and valued their opinions. He was flexible and willing to change plans when necessary. Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor points out that in difficult situations, especially in America, people often want quick solutions. However, sometimes it is better to wait and see how things develop.

Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he noticed Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He insisted that Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t. Another time, during a previous expedition, Shackleton offered to leave a biscuit in the snow rather than eat it himself, showing how much he valued sharing with his team.

As Caroline Alexander, author of *Endurance*, says: "The public's interest in heroic efforts is growing. Shackleton represents the ideals we long for today."

**Simplified Text: 'Finding Food in Madagascar'**

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special primate called the aye-aye. Its way of finding food is similar to that of a woodpecker. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insect larvae by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and pull out the insects.

Although scientists first described the aye-aye's unique feeding method over a hundred years ago, they have only recently learned how it finds the insects hidden in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of two male aye-ayes named Nosferatu and Poe, a female named Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle.

Dr. Erickson wanted to see if the aye-ayes could find insects by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered. He gave them logs with narrow holes. Some holes led to food, while others were empty. The aye-ayes quickly went to the logs with food, showing they did not need to see the holes to find it. They might have been using their sense of smell or hearing, but further tests showed they did not rely on these senses either. They could find food even when the smell was blocked and when the insects were dead and silent.

So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they could sense the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long finger and listens carefully. Dr. Erickson believes the aye-aye uses a method called echo-location, where it listens for sounds that tell it there is a hollow space below. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed by the tapping.

Some scientists think that the aye-aye might fill the role of woodpeckers in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat, but it also acts like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat out.

**Text: Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**

Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but how many of us really know what their lives were like when they were young? The few diaries we have are often incomplete, and family stories are sometimes only half-remembered. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but those images are still flat.

Hannah Renier has found a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with illustrations if needed. Her work focuses on ordinary people, not famous ones. The idea came to her when she spoke with her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. "When I started, I didn’t take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I met people who have interesting stories to tell. They often say they are doing it for their children or future generations, but they enjoy the process too."

The promise of confidentiality helps her subjects feel free to share their true feelings. One man, who is 62 years old, said, "I had the confidence to be honest. I was surprised by what I shared. There were painful memories, like my divorce." He wrote his story for his family, hoping they could learn from it, but he hasn’t let them read it yet. He feels some details might hurt them, and he prefers they read it after he is gone.

Ms. Renier has noticed that many people are influenced by their childhood experiences. "It’s amazing how much people are shaped by their parents," she says. "The messages they received as children can affect them for their whole lives. They often repeat the same patterns in their relationships." Many people still regret things that happened with their parents, even many years later. If they had issues in their youth, they often still have them as adults.

Ms. Renier acts as a recorder rather than an interrogator. "I’m not there to pry into their lives," she explains. People sometimes share things and then worry if they should be included. She usually includes everything, allowing them to remove parts later if they want. Most people want to be honest about their lives.

This is not vanity publishing; it’s not about people saying, "Look at my interesting life." Life is moving quickly, and we are losing touch with our past. These books help people connect with their roots and ancestors, especially since families are not as close as they used to be. People want a way to be remembered.

Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story, organizing the events and interpreting them. Modern technology helps her create everything except the binding, which has gold lettering. Clients can choose the color and title of their book. The final product is well-organized and written, and it looks professional. Each book costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies available for £25 each. She receives about 10 inquiries a week, but the high cost stops many people from ordering. "I thought it would be a more affordable product," she says. "But the people I’ve worked with are often from wealthy backgrounds, readers of magazines like Harpers & Queen, which is where I advertise. They are the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted in the past."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology is one of the few places in the world that has a collection of casts of Greek and Roman sculptures, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to note that none of the sculptures are original; they are all replicas made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is located in a specially designed gallery with great natural light. There are many benefits to having plaster casts: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together again. You can see almost all the famous works of Greek and Roman sculpture in just one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center that has community darkrooms and a gallery displaying various photography exhibitions. We regularly offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows all members to use our darkrooms. We also support young photographers (ages 12 to 16) to improve their skills through our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and provide a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, created by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens stored in their original cabinets from the early 18th century. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and the keeper of the Woodwardian collection. Throughout his life, he greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, allowing visitors to see the major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with full labels explaining their nature and modern uses.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University has its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs across Great Britain. These photographs are interesting as they provide a detailed record of the landscape, showing both the natural environment and human impact from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with any questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but copies can usually be purchased. These copies are made to order and typically take about a month.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world, making it one of the most unique tourist attractions in the region. Visitors can enjoy creating wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. By making resin copies, known as facsimiles, the center preserves the originals while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. The brass plates, which served as memorials to tomb statues, spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, with the widest range available at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Paternity**

**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have been lucky to spend 35 years with small children, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I enjoyed feeding the baby, which is what being a father means to me. I feel very fortunate with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I see them more as a friend than just a father. I do not believe in physical punishment. I have sometimes slapped my children in anger, but I do not support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I am here for them if they need me, but I believe they should reach out to me first. If I start asking them why they haven’t contacted me, it can make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do that to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, around 25, and I found the responsibilities quite annoying. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me stay connected in my work. I missed some important moments when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to the south of France, and they enjoy spending time with my friends and attending parties and award ceremonies without feeling out of place. I think it helps that my job is seen as interesting and glamorous.

**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and I had more children soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as my political career grew, finding time became difficult. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if my children can come with me. If I didn’t do this, they would feel left out. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they don’t feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their children to work, which shows we are becoming more aware of the importance of including our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about fatherhood. I worked hard to stay connected with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while, so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I wonder if I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my children like adults too soon. Kate recently said that we were too lenient. I think I could have set more rules and structure. Instead, I took a very relaxed approach, and I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as my youngest. In that way, your children never really leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for children. I was 30, had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter, Betty, has made me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also means you become just one of many parents. It can be frustrating at times, but whenever I feel annoyed, one look at her makes it all better. A baby's smile is the best way to feel happy again.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's ten-act play about a powerful warrior can feel long, but Terry Hands' production makes it one of the most exciting nights of the year. He has cut parts of the text and created a show that combines the beauty of Marlowe's writing with fast-paced action. Antony Sher shines in the lead role, performing impressive stunts while capturing the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power and glory. Great performance!  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, which was first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second act, the setting changes, and the play becomes a moving study of the effects of illness. The British theatre lost a great talent when Wall passed away at the young age of 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is the latest Irish playwright to enrich the English stage. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one looks at the decline of the fishing industry with a mix of strong characters, deep emotions, and moments of humor. The play sometimes feels a bit aimless, but it builds to an exciting ending.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This traditional thriller involves the idea of 'the perfect murder.' Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play crime writers who plan to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the twists are cleverly done.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes finds the value in Jonson's great comedy about 17th-century con artists. First seen at the Swan in Stratford last year, the show works just as well on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce giving excellent performances as the trio of tricksters.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after its success at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This charming new musical features playwright Alan Ayckbourn in a positive mood as he sets the Beauty and the Beast story in a London suburb. With a beautiful score by John Pattison and a heartfelt celebration of romantic love, this show is sure to be a hit. London producers looking for success should visit Scarborough.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy almost received a negative review, but it is saved by strong comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Many other actors seem a bit uncomfortable, which is understandable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. The story is about a seemingly respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a suspicious bookshop. She discovers that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to separate her from her friends. The characters of her friends are well described by Coppard. The book shows the details of family life, the bonds of childhood friendship, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It is an important and convincing read.

Two teenagers, Jack, who comes from a poor background, and Rill, who goes to a fancy girls' school, team up when they find out that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. Different viewpoints and documents like maps and personal accounts help the reader understand what happened. This is a clever and complex novel that requires careful reading.

Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and the male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story has a clear message: "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
In this chilling story, Robert Westall tells the tale from the perspective of a mature woman. Rose rents a cottage from Sepp Yaxley to escape her materialistic life and her arrogant husband, bringing her two children with her. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage reveal why Yaxley disappeared. However, their presence causes local people to become hostile, putting their lives in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is still troubled by her son's cold behavior. It is a gripping story.

Sam is a chubby, talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, who comes from a wealthy family. **Text: 'Science Defying Gravity'**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are using weightlessness to test their ideas. The aircraft looked like a normal plane from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, based on the Boeing 707. However, inside, it was very different. The interior was a long white tunnel with few windows and lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, leaving only a few at the back where the nervous students sat.

For a year, these students had competed to take part in this flight, which was organized by the European Space Agency. They had to come up with creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. Those with the best ideas won a spot on this special flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride. 

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly in a way that felt like a giant bird soaring up and then diving down. The pilot would cut the engines at 3,000 meters, allowing the plane to rise higher for a moment before gravity pulled it back down. During the few seconds of weightlessness, the students would feel as if they were closer to the moon than to the Earth.

The flight started smoothly, but the students quickly realized this was not a regular passenger flight when the pilot made the plane climb at a steep angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and the students felt the blood rush from their heads as they were pushed against the cabin floor. Then, the engines stopped, and they experienced weightlessness almost immediately. For 20 seconds, they floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. Moving around became confusing; directions like left, right, up, or down lost their meaning.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. The return of gravity was sudden, and some students landed hard. After completing the first curve, some students felt sick at the thought of the 29 more to come. Thirty curves meant ten minutes of "space time" for their experiments. The Dutch students studied the movements of their robotic cat, Leonardo, to find out how cats always land on their feet. They released a device they built to investigate this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. 

However, during the next curve, another student accidentally landed on top of it. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how the quality of metal joints is affected by the lack of gravity, which is important for building future space stations. Another group from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films that harden in ultraviolet sunlight. They believe that if they perfect this process, satellites could use solar sails to harness the sun's energy, just like a yacht uses wind.

After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, the students felt a mix of excitement and instability, but mostly exhilaration. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**Simplified Text:**

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**  
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*. 

I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t experience any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I had nine winters in a row, which I enjoyed because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then it can be yours.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was suitable for planting trees. I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me, and I was eager to start. My family also became enthusiastic as we went along. I began planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it was a very rainy winter. It rained almost every day while we were planting, and I don’t think I have ever been so wet or cold for such a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready for the next planting session. I would come out of the Land Rover warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and my clothes were still damp from the day before. My hands would struggle with slippery shoelaces. “My mind would start to wander, allowing me to think about many strange ideas and reflections on life.” 

In that first year, I had a helper who was an experienced tree-planter, which was very useful since I had never planted trees seriously before. You wear a planting bag around your neck, filling it with as many trees as you can. When the bag is full, it becomes heavy, and it only gets easier when it is lighter. The hardest part of the job was getting the lines straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then you set up three poles in a straight line. These poles help you keep your planting straight. Once you are in line, you plant all the way down the line, then turn around and come back. I enjoy hard physical work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get into a rhythm and use the least number of movements to dig the hole. 

The rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You train your body to do the same movements, and then it becomes easy: you take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, put it in the ground, stamp it down, and move on. Mentally, it is interesting. My mind would start to think about many ideas and reflections on life. A lot of my thoughts about nature and our place in it began during those days. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which has been very satisfying because I planted them and feel connected to their success. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. Such news makes me anxious. However, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.

I should add that I took a break from teaching and went back in 1984, alone for three months. I wrote my first book there, *Seeing Green*. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I would write; in the afternoons, I would prune the trees, and in the evenings, I would do research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place I feel most connected to in terms of the bond between people and the earth. It is a powerful connection.

**Text: 'RAISING BADGERS'**

"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have run an open dairy farm in Somerset for six years, and we are known for caring for orphaned animals. But the noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was unfamiliar. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were covered in fleas, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badgers are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early lives underground. If they are orphaned, they often die from hunger and are never found. These three cubs were brought to me by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. The mother was found dead, with her babies still trying to suckle. I could see the cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing the fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them beside the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I used a syringe to feed them, but I had to wipe each cub with a warm cloth first to mimic the feeling of their mother licking them. This helped them to go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though a bit unsteadily. They were happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother.

However, three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed weak, even though he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet's examination showed that Willow had died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding any animal, it is important not to let them drink too quickly, as liquid can go into the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that would have been hard to treat, even with antibiotics, because he was so small. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other cubs. Then, six days later, a local farmer, who had heard about our cubs, came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew she would not return because the area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. This new cub, named Willow II, joined us. At six weeks old, he was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon discovered why his mother had left him; he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle's teat around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day.

By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and then anything else. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly learned to chew and eat. After a week of sausages, he was ready for more variety. At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Normally, badgers eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and even plant roots. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.

By August, my badgers had started to become nocturnal and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where the long grass made it easy for them to chase each other. They would get excited, fluff up their fur, and chase their tails. As "human badgers," we joined in their fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, sometimes got caught and had colorful reactions to it.

During two late-night walks in a dry period, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food because badgers are very territorial and will fight others that enter their area. We were warned that they might come into our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we put sheet metal over the gate to keep it safe. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and we started a campaign to build a sett (a badger home) on the farm. With help from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. One of our sons, Daniel, drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate that faced their usual walking path. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they became more interested in the tunnels and bedding than in walking.

The cost of building was higher than we expected, but a local bus company called Badgerline helped fund part of it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I quietly returned to check on them and saw three badgers curled up in their chambers, sound asleep. Nowadays, I don’t walk with them as often, especially since they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined a nearby sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to greet me before running off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have happily accepted.

**Text: In Search of True North - The Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley, who studied compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his most important achievements was mapping the "variations of the compass" during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called "declination," refer to the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Understanding declination was crucial for sailors to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.

Halley, one of only two men in England at that time who were paid to do scientific research, set out for the Cape Verde Islands to chart declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip was cut short due to crew problems, but he later sailed again. This second voyage took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, he published a "New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans." More advanced maps based on his work helped sailors for over a century until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made them less accurate.

Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him.

Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley led a remarkable life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and worked on other projects."

During this time, Halley invented a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica, which is the foundation of classical physics. Dr. Clark believes that recreating Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. It will involve taking measurements that Halley made, but with much better instruments. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.

Dr. Clark explains, "It is common to measure the size of the magnetic field but not its direction. You need to know true north to measure the direction. On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that." The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.

Halley's journey was significant because it was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian appointed as a naval captain to study declination. Does Dr. Clark have the right experience for his voyage? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.

Does he share Halley's obsessive nature? "I am willing to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior raises a question that puzzled Charles Darwin: how could birds develop such extravagant features in a world where survival is tough? How do they manage to do this?

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying the peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers, more than a century after Darwin's death. Darwin believed that living things change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that natural selection was the main way this happened. In a competitive environment, the individuals best suited to survive are the "fittest." However, this usually means the strongest or fastest, not necessarily the most beautiful.

Darwin thought that the peacock's tail was a burden, so he introduced the idea of "sexual selection." He suggested that females are attracted to beauty for its own sake. However, Darwin's friend Alfred Russel Wallace disagreed. He believed that if peahens prefer males with the most impressive tails, there must be another reason behind this choice that is not obvious to humans. According to Wallace, the tail is not just for show; it must indicate some real advantage for survival.

Today, researchers still debate this issue. Studying the natural behavior of peafowl is challenging. However, the 200 peacocks at Whipsnade, which live like wild birds but are used to people, provide a great opportunity for research. Marion Petrie and her team have two main questions: Do peahens really choose the males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have some real advantages, or is it just for show?

The adult male peacocks display in groups, and the hens compare them. Long observations and photographs suggest that the hens do prefer the males with the most eye-spots on their tails, which are related to tail length. Males with more eye-spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University has suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and free from parasites, and their bright feathers could signal this. There is some evidence for this in other bird species, but Dr. Petrie and her team have not yet been able to check for parasites in the Whipsnade peacocks.

This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive males with those of less attractive males. Are the children of the attractive males healthier and growing faster? If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females make choices based on real benefits.

There is also an interesting theory from mathematician and biologist R A Fisher from the 1930s called "Fisher's Runaway." He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will inherit her preference for long tails. This could lead to a situation where males with the longest tails have the most mates, and the preference for long tails increases over generations. Modern computer models show that this could explain the development of the peacock's tail. Interestingly, this would also support Darwin's idea that, once this process starts, females would be selecting beauty for its own sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He applied this idea in his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is filled with beautiful yachts that use the latest technology. Most of these boats come from a major change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although it was designed last year, it looks like it is 100 years old, which might make you think its owner is a romantic. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.

My boat uses the charm of traditional design, but modern technology has made the process easier. However, it is important to note that advanced technology can sometimes keep sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what they wanted to experience by going sailing in the first place. I am not saying that sailors should go back to facing every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if every sail can set itself? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.

Why should we change the steering position from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less secure spot near the front? Unfortunately, this change makes the cabin feel like a large room on a cruise ship, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water.

When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race series, the previous owner said it had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over time, I learned how true that was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I have ever sailed.

However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care because they are old. When I hurt my back, I realized I could no longer take care of her. I looked for a younger boat but found nothing suitable, so I decided to build a new one from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, are skilled with computer design, Irens first sketched this boat on a paper napkin before using a computer. After creating a model, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.

The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the water, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside, much of which is made from reclaimed pitch pine. This may be because she was designed purely as a sailing boat, without thinking about any furniture we might add. This traditional method works well. In her calmness, she shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it is wise to learn from history. Built with special treated wood, she is completely waterproof. So, she has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but still looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started attending body conditioning classes, yoga, and other activities. The instructors are very well trained. I was surprised at how flexible I felt as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. **NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not developed many differences. Genetically, we are still more than 98% similar to chimps. This means that the things that make us different from animals are very recent. Our biological history suggests that our ability to create art and other unique human traits come from just a small part of our genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.

Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be unique to humans are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings suggest that there are not many absolute differences between humans and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost 6.9 million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art may have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.

If we believe that our recent artistic creativity makes us different, we need to consider how our art is different from that of animals. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is created for beauty, and it is learned rather than instinctive.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas or feelings, this is not the same as passing on genes. In contrast, birdsong has clear purposes, like defending territory or attracting a mate, which helps them pass on their genes. By this standard, human art does seem different.

The second claim is that human art is motivated by a desire for beauty. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mainly sing during the breeding season, suggesting they do not sing just for pleasure. Again, this makes human art seem unique.

The third claim is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. However, these differences are not in the singers' genes. People from different cultures can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' songs, even if they have never heard them before.

The role of learning in human art is also clear because our art styles change quickly. For example, geese have made the same sounds for 2,000 years, but human art evolves rapidly. Even casual museum visitors can tell that a painting from the twentieth century is newer than the Mona Lisa. Art experts can often identify when and who painted a work, but they might confuse two mid-twentieth-century artists named Congo and Betsy. In reality, these artists were chimpanzees. Congo created up to 33 paintings in one day and became upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show of their paintings in 1957 in London, and many of their works sold, which is something many human artists cannot achieve.

These paintings by chimpanzees blur the lines between human art and animal behavior. Like human art, the ape paintings were not created for practical purposes; they were made for the satisfaction of the painter. You might argue that human art is different because most human artists intend to communicate with others, while the apes did not care about sharing their paintings. However, this argument is not very strong, as some famous human art was also created for personal satisfaction.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also one of the most dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell the story. There are very few big adventures left and very few heroes. Children's stories used to be about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on distant horizons. Today, such characters are rare in fiction and in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's great adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert, which means "once entered, you never come out." Local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while at home with his family. His team included four Britons (one was a medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have endangered everyone’s lives and the success of the expedition.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's harshest deserts, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I was outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back since nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was surprisingly good to us."

Anyone reading his incredible story will wonder why he used the word "kind." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us completely. That doesn’t mean we didn’t face challenges all the time. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often rolled over onto us."

"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."

If it was tough at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you’re not going to give up. You’ve endured so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite our exhaustion. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."

Midway through the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How aware was he of how hard it must have been for them? "Inside me, there’s someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the image of the desert and remember that we managed to complete that journey. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I’ve done. Yet, when I think of my life’s achievements, I think of my family and the happiness we share — by that measure, the desert does not compare."

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge — for the open spaces — the excitement of it all. We were motivated by a sense of purpose. I find it hard now to fit into the sameness of modern life."

Hurst's desire for perfection is a big part of his success, along with his talent. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He believes that furniture should be practical and useful, not just a statement.

**Three Theories About Sleep**

People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.

The first and most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our physical health. It suggests that while we sleep, our bodies work to repair any damage from the day and help us feel better.

The second theory focuses on learning. It claims that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. According to this theory, without sleep, we would not be able to learn effectively.

The third theory is about energy. It says that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, so we are ready for the next day. 

These theories show that sleep plays an important role in our lives, but the exact reasons are still being studied.

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and does not follow the accepted rules of society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Most of us have our own quirks and strange habits. For example, someone might love entering newspaper competitions, collect beer mats, or write angry letters to the press about various topics. Eccentricity shows our individuality.

Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces: individualism and conformity. Individualism is the desire to be unique, while conformity is the desire to fit in with others. Most people want to be accepted and liked, which makes conformity stronger than the desire to stand out. 

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as strange. Being part of a group can be comforting. Many of us feel a tension between wanting to fit in and wanting to be different. Even when we follow the crowd, we may feel the need to show our individuality. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me."

At any time, we can choose to express our individuality. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, once said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it without giving up. This may confuse others." However, this strong expression of individuality is not the same as eccentricity, especially at first. 

If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become a part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric. The key to eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they simply are.

True eccentrics are not focused on what others think. They act according to who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often react to it. Some want to impress others, while others want to escape from society. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have had the chance to meet many important figures in this field. One of the most significant is Barbara Ward, a small but strong woman. She has been at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own powerful ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." However, I believe her most important book is "The Home of Man." Although its title sounds old-fashioned, it focuses on the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a passionate call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none compare to it.

**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication through words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see that their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a respected behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His collaboration with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's simple yet effective paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm. This is the work of a true naturalist.

**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was studying animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, opening this book made my world brighter. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and nature—a small example of a world worth saving. Some people say humans are the worst because of the harm we have caused to other species. However, I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living beings as a family, connected and inseparable. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.

**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library shortly after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially to the 48 colorful bird illustrations by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered much more. Along with the beautiful illustrations, it included chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. The wide range of information and exciting images encouraged me to appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. The book showed me that my emotional and creative connection to nature is just as important as a scientific one. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new possibilities for myself.

**Do Reviews Sell Books?**

We asked five important British publishers about how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers often think that even bad reviews can help sales because they get people interested. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinions about a book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago, but many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers need reviews because they are a cost-effective way to promote a book and its author. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several positive reviews.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. Many of the books we publish are not by famous authors, so we rely on reviews from literary editors. Good reviews are often more valuable than ads because they show that the review is not influenced by money. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help launch a book and a writer's career, but they need support from other factors like recommendations and marketing.

**Publisher D**  
The relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain is complicated. In the United States, a single review from the New York Times can make or break a book. In Britain, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a talented writer. Interestingly, some poorly reviewed books can still sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than on the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews, but do they really sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. The name of the reviewer can matter. Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people would pay attention. Today, an unexpected reviewer or a clever review can also encourage people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, dating back to ancient Egypt. Today, this skill is still practiced in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something unique that reflects the man's job or hobbies.

Graham's work is different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. "I realized that there are endless possibilities for designs," he explains. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change their roles—she went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for their children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he has no regrets about this change. "My previous job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."

Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs available because they are still popular. "People like handmade items," Graham says. "They appreciate having something a little different."

Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I feel satisfied when a simple shape becomes something almost lifelike," he explains. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction." He adds that more people are moving to the countryside and want to add a special touch to their homes, which has helped crafts like his.

Graham is now busier than ever, sending weathervanes to customers around the world. He has noticed a lot of interest from buyers in America and Denmark. "The price depends on how detailed the design is," he explains. His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, *The Horse Whisperer* was the most talked-about book of the year. This first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans made him a lot of money. He shares his story about his inspiration and success.

At the start of the year, Nicholas Evans was having a tough time. A film project he had been working on, called *Life and Limb*, fell apart suddenly. He was worried because it had been two years since he had earned any money, and he was in debt to his bank. A sensible person in his situation would have found a job, maybe returning to television. But instead, he made a surprising choice. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching for his first novel.

Although he acted on impulse, the idea for his story had been in his mind for a while. He had met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) while visiting a friend in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a gentle horse that suddenly became aggressive. The owners were desperate until they heard about a gypsy who could calm the horse just by talking to it. These special people were called "horse whisperers." This story inspired Evans.

He started to research horse whisperers, thinking about writing a screenplay since he was a filmmaker. However, after the failure of *Life and Limb*, he decided to write the story as a book. During the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He later said, "It was a strange time. I was watching people, but I felt alone and worried about my life. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt and unsure how to support my family."

By the end of August, after returning home, he had written the first half of the book. He was still worried about money and needed to know if he should continue. He showed the manuscript to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent read it and said it was "fine." When asked for an estimate, he suggested Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. Evans thought about how much he needed to pay off some of his debts, and $30,000 was not enough. He had spent seven months on *The Horse Whisperer* and still had at least two months of work left. He was also told to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book.

In October, he sent the first two hundred pages of the novel and the summary to seven UK publishers just before they went to the Frankfurt Book Fair. Soon, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. Evans was shocked and asked, "What?" The agent replied, "It's okay, I feel something good is happening."

What happened next is now famous in publishing. Within a week of competitive bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for £550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans and his team were amazed. They had not even sent the manuscript to New York, and they still do not know how it got there. They also did not send it to Hollywood, but soon major film studios were interested in it. Evans's UK agent worked with an American agent, who called to say, "I think we can get $3 million for it." They all laughed in disbelief.

That October night, Evans sat in his study while four famous filmmakers called him one after another, asking to pay $3 million for his unfinished novel. He shared this story while we drank coffee on his porch overlooking his garden. He mentioned that he had turned down an offer to write the screenplay for *The Horse Whisperer*. "It's been like a fairy tale," he said. "I don't want to ruin it. Writing at that level is very hard, and I don’t want to become just an employee of these people who have paid me so much. I would hate to write a draft and then have them say, 'Thanks, Nick, but we’ll hire someone else now.'"

He wanted to stay involved but from a distance. The success of his novel led to new support for *Life and Limb*, but he was unsure if he wanted to make it anymore. "I think it would be foolish not to write another novel," he said.

**Young Masters**

Bobby Fischer is facing challenges as he tries to return to chess. Chess is now more of a young person's game. After being away from the game for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in great shape. Spassky is even older. 

Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, leading to a new level of professionalism in the game. Now, winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time; if they don’t, they lose the game. Nowadays, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This increased pressure favors younger players. Over the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the last. Currently, eight of the ten highest-ranked players are under 30.

The way chess is played has also changed. Much of modern chess preparation happens off the board. Players must prepare seriously before matches, especially because computers have changed the game. A small computer can store one million chess games and provide quick access to many games of an opponent. In recent matches, players have used large teams to analyze each other’s strategies.
