The opening moves of a game are studied in great detail, and being well-prepared can be crucial.

Today, there are more top players than ever before, and many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. A moment of distraction can lead to losing the game. The chess clock adds to the stress, especially during the final moments when players have only seconds to make their moves. In these intense moments, players must act quickly and efficiently, similar to athletes.

At the highest level of chess, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess masters must be ready for the next challenge every day. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games played daily, and there are competitions throughout the year. World championship matches can be even more demanding. For example, the 1984 match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to be stopped after several months because both players were exhausted. Karpov lost about 10 kg during the match.

Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This makes his decision to leave the chess world after 1972 seem strange. However, it also made him a legend. If he has returned for the money, he is in a good position, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones interviews some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are on their way to success.

**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. "It's low budget, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be over £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Nick is very talented, but what is surprising is that he had never been to a play or read one before writing *Peaches*. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he explains. "It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know the problems it can cause. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational setting. It was very inspiring."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is currently writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his partnership with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was imitating him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became well-known when he starred in the series *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a comfortable position for him, especially since he has just graduated. Looking back at his early career, it's clear that he was always meant to succeed. Encouraged by his mother, he went from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he spent four years. "I was basically using acting to avoid doing homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided I wanted to take it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for the praise to come in, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about earning respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. "The record company's idea of good sales is very different from mine," he says. "They want a big hit, but I just want two people to buy it and be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music industry ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards is 27 years old and has won many awards and honors, more than most people twice his age. He is already well-known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. "I decided not to go to university, but I became bored stuffing envelopes at a theater and realized I should go." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry receiving much praise, moving into novels is a brave step. "My poetry has a structure, and there's less chance of making big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more words that could be bad. My main goal is to avoid just producing work without caring about its quality."

**Simplified Text:**

A. Isabel, the main character in this fun novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but rarely wears them because she doesn’t want to be seen with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance stories. Isabel is looking for the right man but worries that her knobbly knees might stop her from finding him. Despite her worries, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with a lively style, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired," similar to the dramatic pace of early silent films.

B. This story celebrates the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart, shy child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing, taking readers back to the kinder days of the 1940s and 1950s, filled with old stores, classic cars, and radio shows.

C. In the author's world, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife’s first husband. When Richard Vaisey, a successful professor, falls for a beautiful Russian poet, he shares his feelings with his wife’s ex-husband. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also trying to get help for her brother, who is wrongly imprisoned. However, the way the author tells this story is what makes it interesting. He moves the plot forward with a sense of humor and carefully examines the relationships, making it an enjoyable and clever read.

D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become connected for 25 years through life and death. At the beginning of this long novel, James Hudson, a mysterious American businessman, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved (and one of them married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is strong. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters and become deeply involved in their lives.

E. This touching and funny story is written by one of the best American authors. It follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an unusual bachelor. The story explores many emotions and highlights the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that perfectly balances sadness and humor.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four academic writers discuss international volunteer work.

A. It is difficult to say that volunteer tourists make a big difference in development. While they can help build homes or schools, they usually pay a lot of money to participate in these projects. This money could be better used if donated directly to local communities, as it could pay for more labor than one volunteer can provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often lack the necessary skills or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers are truly motivated by a desire to help others or if they are more interested in gaining experience that will help their careers. However, these projects can help develop people who may act ethically in their future careers.

B. Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, improved conflict resolution skills, and increased participation in global issues through civic organizations. It can also help build international social networks among everyday people. In this way, the overall benefits can be greater than the individual contributions, helping both volunteers and local communities. However, if volunteering is mostly done by wealthy individuals, it may only benefit them and not the communities that need help.

C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that serves the interests of wealthy Westerners rather than the communities they aim to help. On the other hand, it can also provide valuable technical assistance for development. When done well, international volunteering can benefit both volunteers and the organizations they work with, while also allowing for the sharing of skills and cultural experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness about issues like poverty and injustice.

D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the growing trend of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially in a time when people are skeptical of big government and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity, which may not truly change the situations of poor communities. While volunteering can be a good thing, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can lead to misunderstandings about real development issues. The focus on volunteer tourism can distract from the serious global inequalities and poverty faced by many in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**

Stuart Harris reports

Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and most of us need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group that included myself, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges tested five clock radios that are currently available.

One model has a 'dual alarm function', which I thought meant you could wake up to a buzzer, snooze for a bit, and then get up. However, the instruction booklet says this function is for setting two different wake-up times: one for weekdays and one for weekends. But who really lives like that? This model costs about the same as another one we tested, but it has a cassette player, which is a nice feature. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to music instead of news. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size is a problem; it is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges mentioned that he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also said he always books a wake-up call just in case the alarm fails.

This model was voted the best overall. Paul Bridges said he was 'in love with it', even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it without opening your eyes. However, the smooth buttons made me want to touch them like piano keys, which caused problems when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out, which we all liked. However, we found it difficult to set up, but once we did, we felt pretty good about it.

Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, was 'very tacky'. He had to pull the light out of its socket to make it work, which made him question the quality of the whole thing. He read the instruction booklet twice before he could get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The light was hard to position; it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine and made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people, with its bright colors and fun design, which appealed to both Tom Granger and me. Tom said, 'I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others.' 

The traditional controls made it the only model we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm has a funny 20-minute error margin; the manual says, 'the alarm may sound about 10 minutes earlier or later than the set time.' Paul Bridges laughed at this idea, saying the model was 'very tricky' and 'completely useless'. 

The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was 'very standard and took up little space', and it has old-fashioned dial tuning. He said, 'It's easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed the buttons correctly, so you can’t be confident it will work.' He agreed that manufacturers had to improve radio quality because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was a bit rough, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was good. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**

A hedgehog is a small mammal known for the sharp spines that cover its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All types of hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are attacked, which makes their spines point outwards. This is a good way to protect themselves, but it depends on how many spines they have. Some desert hedgehogs have adapted to their environment and have fewer spines, so they are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up.

Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs will stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Excelling in any sport is challenging, even for men, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competing leave little time for a normal life, so they must make sacrifices. Despite these challenges, they are overcoming prejudice and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are achieving their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or it’s windy, and I can’t see well, but I just keep going. It’s hard to have a life outside skiing because we train for ten months each year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated equally - it’s a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing since I had never cycled before! I earn a good salary as a professional, and cycling has many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks, not because I’m a great cyclist. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day on the bike, plus I do some stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls to start because very few girls' schools offer it. Most girls don’t begin until they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches often change every year, so the women’s team lacks stability. But it’s a lot of fun, and I love being fit, plus there’s a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and wanted freedom. Each walk has been different. The walk across Australia was the hardest experience for me. I walked 50 miles a day with very little sleep and many blisters on my feet. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when they drive. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I reach a corner, men think, 'I have to beat her,' so I’ve had many tough moments! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It’s hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are starting to race every year. For me, the excitement of saloon car racing is always trying to achieve a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of nervousness before a race, and when I compete, I really push myself. I don’t feel good if I don’t. I’ve often asked myself why I do this. The answers are: a) I’m happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the articles focus on the men’s events, and only 10% mention the women’s. The prize money is also not as good. But now we have formed an International Triathlon Women’s Commission to improve this."

**Simplified Text:**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could easily recognize Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was very surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. Without my friend's encouragement, I would not have had the courage to go over and ask for his signature. I was nervous when I introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, but to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added some lively lines below. Picasso's art often reflected real things, so those lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a shy conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped us communicate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak freely. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and said, "Is that all? Why don’t you go back and take advantage of this chance? He probably wouldn’t mind if you drew his portrait."

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I thought it was better not to ask if I could draw him, as he might say no and ruin the moment. So, I just stood by the table, set my pad against a screen, took out a crayon, and started to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled playfully and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny expressions, rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue, like a clown. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit challenged me to keep going. 

Eventually, Picasso relaxed and let me study him without distractions. I noticed how strong and alert he looked, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he seemed a bit distant and alone. He let his friends talk while he quietly focused on his own thoughts.

When the American lady told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt embarrassed and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded approvingly. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he drew a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes onto my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks.

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American lady explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he had some limits to his generosity! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This text explains some of the tricks that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets know that customers really like fresh food. To create this feeling, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The way products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store customers visit the most. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are especially popular with manufacturers. Special bins with discounts attract bargain hunters. Another strategy is to place related items together, like putting salad dressings near ice cream or burgers.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, customers have to walk past more expensive items to get to them. Chain stores also place popular products away from the entrance, hoping that loyal customers will search for them and see other tempting products along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from the idea of selling many items cheaply. Instead, they create a boutique feel by showing fewer items, making them seem exclusive. Their success comes from good store design as well as stylish clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**  
Food shoppers often pay more attention to the total cost of their shopping than to the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with more expensive items to attract customers. They sometimes sell certain staples at a loss to bring people in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They also get low prices by buying in large amounts or by promoting products prominently.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Customers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and notice prices more. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores pay attention to lighting. Chain stores try to use lighting that looks like natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.

**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different types of flooring to guide customers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, while another marks sales areas. This strategy, called the "Yellow Brick Road," encourages shoppers to follow certain routes. For example, Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths to lead customers to more inviting carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**  
As you enter a supermarket, you might see large, colorful pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry if you haven't eaten. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and can increase sales significantly.

**Text: Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, 58, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin to ask for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sail. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first time on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

When we reached a steep drop, I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. He hadn’t, so I showed him how to do it. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could go down the way he used ropes on his boat. He was used to using his arms, but I wanted him to use his legs. I was not very happy about it, but he managed to lower himself down safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I built a strong friendship. His idea to combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural next step after our voyage to Skye.

Robin impressed me as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked for everyone’s opinion first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. To be honest, I found sailing difficult and boring. The moments of crisis were easy to handle because of the excitement, but spending days in the middle of the sea was hard for me. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, is a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was also very close together: six people on a 32-foot yacht that was meant for four. When you are on a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other. When we reached Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many times when if Robin had fallen, he could have pulled me down with him. I had to be careful about that. I also underestimated how hard climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were climbing for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin worked very hard, but he completely trusted me and just followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted it. I knew that Robin was worried about the boat: whether it would get through the ice and if it was still okay. Still, he wanted to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time we had a problem in our relationship was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns to keep watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me because he thought he could handle it alone. The night before, I had almost fallen asleep. I felt that he didn’t trust me, which made me feel insecure, and I told him so. Robin quickly reassured me that I was misunderstanding the situation. While we enjoyed the trip to Skye, we didn’t really get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life for a very long time, with many different types in various colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this important part of our heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, they left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, early humans even stored dried apple halves for the winter. These apples were wild crab apples, small and not very tasty, which were known in Ancient Britain as "windings." They were very different from the apples we eat today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in the British climate. After the Norman Conquest, new apple varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new types of apples, which are the ancestors of many Western apples today.

**Medieval Apples (1200)**  
In the thirteenth century, several apple types became common in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a popular cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century. However, due to droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, apple production decreased, and more apples were imported. This changed in the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many new apple varieties, including the famous Pippins, and started the first modern orchard in Kent.

**Settlers and Apples (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers who went to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought apples to Australia, and Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa. The Pilgrim Fathers on the Mayflower also carried apples to America. In North America, the famous apple planter was John Chapman, known as "Johnny Appleseed." Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans saw him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees and unique clothing led to many stories about him.

**Modern Apples (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa found a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple "Hawkey." When he showed it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was sold as "Delicious" and became one of the most popular apples worldwide.

Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was discovered in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was the daughter of convicts and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. Known as "Granny Smith," she took care of her family's farm. In 1868, she found a small tree growing from discarded fruit and transplanted it. Soon, she harvested the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. She remarked that it was like God to make something useful from what we consider rubbish, referring to both the apple and her own background.

**The Problem of Uniformity (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, from India to Africa. However, most apples come from only a few varieties, chosen for their appearance or how well they travel, rather than their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the diversity of apples. While some amateur gardeners in the UK have kept old apple varieties alive, the US has lost many apple types from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are starting to want more variety. It is important that we all work to protect the diversity of apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups Leave Few Footprints**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique and interesting destinations with original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last between 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, averaging 16 people, and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local cultures. It’s a rewarding experience for all travelers.

**Different Modes of Travel**

We use various types of transport during our trips, often on the same journey. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who are ready to face new challenges and enjoy unique adventures. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old, with about half being couples and the rest solo travelers.

**Activities and Interests**

It’s hard to define Explore Worldwide because each trip is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories, each highlighting special activities. These highlights, along with unique places and local experiences, contribute to the enjoyment of your holiday.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural aspect, with some focusing mainly on local cultures and historical sites. For example, trips to Egypt, Jordan, Turkey, India, and many other countries offer rich cultural experiences. Short walks of 2-4 hours to visit less-known sites are often included.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing you to see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might even step outside your vehicle to explore the wild. You can track gorillas in Zaire, hike with tribal guides in Uganda, or canoe on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel stays.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal peoples, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara or the Maya of Mexico. Many of these cultures are under threat, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. You can also hike from village to village, sometimes staying in local homes or simple huts. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, Morocco, and Thailand. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high altitudes. You may stay with local people or camp in stunning mountain ranges like the Himalayas or the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the beauty of the Amazon Rainforest or the mystique of the Sahara Desert. These trips offer a chance to experience something truly special.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats. You can sail through Upper Egypt, explore the islands of Greece and Thailand, or cruise the Galapagos Islands on a small yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

Our river journeys can last from a few hours to several days. You can paddle your own inflatable boat or enjoy thrilling whitewater rafting with skilled guides. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river trips in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of beautiful landscapes and wildlife.

**Simplified Text:**

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner from Britain, visits a training camp in Kenya. This camp is located ten miles south of the equator, on a mountain path that leads to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For the past three years, this beautiful but isolated place, called Nanyuk, has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners before. On my fourth trip to Kenya, I decided to change that. I participated in my first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I was invited by the national team coach after I finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss.

Training at high altitude helps produce more red blood cells, which improves how well the body carries oxygen. This has helped many Kenyan runners succeed. My first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent, in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience for me, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and almost all of them were Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I know that Kenyan success is not just because of the altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple and effective approach to running. They run effortlessly, eat simple food, and enjoy competing.

During my time at the training camp, I learned how the Kenyan runners train. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The living conditions are basic; the athletes share rooms with college students. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a light morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. Each day starts at six in the morning, and we gather to hear instructions from the coaches. We were told to take it easy during the morning run because we had a tough day ahead. We ran about 40 kilometers each day, which is just under a marathon distance. On Sundays, we only ran 20 kilometers, which was a nice break from the other days.

Life at the camp was simple. We only needed a splash of water on our faces and a quick brush of our teeth before breakfast. Breakfast included tea, bread, and boiled eggs, eaten in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner were similar, with ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to a stream to wash off in the evening. By the end of my stay, I had a deeper understanding of why Kenyan runners are so successful. Their success is not just due to genetics, upbringing, or altitude. I began to think that the simple lifestyle in the mountains, their hard training, and their passion for running might be the real reasons behind Kenya's success in distance running.

**Text: The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem started in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The decline in advertising is happening all over the world. The main issue is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large audiences and mass media, but as more brands and media options have appeared, audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.

Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen brands a year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and you may only buy a new one every three years. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Overall, you probably do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year.

In comparison, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are listed and analyzed. The average person buys only 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are because of advertising. This means that about 96% of advertising may not lead to sales, but no one knows which 96% is wasted.

When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy in the future. Most people find that only about 6% of the commercials are relevant to them, meaning that 94% of the ads may be wasted. Many people believe they are not influenced by advertising, but the truth is that most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is a natural part of advertising. It is unrealistic to think that every person who sees an ad will rush out to buy the product. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable.

However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many ads have shown that they can work. Advertisers need to reach a large number of people to find the few who will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested. Media advertising is a cost-effective way to communicate with many people. With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who are likely to respond, but they can never know exactly who will respond.

Even the best direct mail campaigns do not get a 100% response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and face-to-face selling. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use media at all; they could contact those people directly.

Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers (about 2% of the adult population) is doing well. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can attract 2% of the population would be considered very successful, even though this is a small part of the population. The most effective way to reach them may still be through mass media, but for advertising to improve, it needs to be more focused than ever before.

**Simplified Text:**

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits Britain's Greenest Home**

In Southwell, Nottinghamshire, there are some interesting surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral that many people do not know about. It is famous for its 'green' men, which are pagan figures carved by craftsmen in the thirteenth century. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' which is the greenest home in Britain. It was designed and built by Robert and Brenda Vale.

The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their sewage into compost for their garden, and heat their home using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's nineteenth-century buildings and was approved by planners, even though it is in a conservation area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice it is very quiet inside. The house is super-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists on this. The house feels very calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it ventilates the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create air movement because the house is designed to be draught-proof. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for a long time. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They first designed a building that produced no carbon dioxide, and then they decided to also avoid using mains water. They created composting toilets, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep the drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.

Robert says, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is much better for the environment without living in darkness." The only medieval feature of the house is its design: the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, goes all the way up to the roof. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.

Soon, they will install solar water heating panels and equipment in the garden, which will help the house generate more electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will produce extra electricity, enough to charge an electric car in the future. The only heating source is a small wood-burning stove in the hall, which they only use during the coldest winter days. 

When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no draughts and everything was at the same temperature. He compared this to an Edwardian lady who felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggested that people living in old houses should go back to how people lived in the past, but this idea might be hard for many to accept.

The secret of the house is that it is low-tech and simple, so there is little that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a local builder's merchant and installed by local workers, making the house affordable to build. It cost the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial building companies are not happy with this idea.

**Text: The Camera Can Deceive**

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article, accepting fairies as magical beings. 

It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that a basic idea about photography is wrong: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and it always has been able to. 

Today, we often use computer software to change our digital images, and it is a myth that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Text: Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured the human imagination, and blacksmiths, the people who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were respected like doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more creative approach to interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with manufacturers advertising their products as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks and other similar items.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote their craft. The first event is an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), which opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be at the start of a new Iron Age, because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson adds, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves."

About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual makers, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote good ironwork. Dawson's own contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He explains, "My style comes from letting steel bend and flow into shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space."

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable." Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever."

No other metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used for decorative purposes for many years to come, as long as we can avoid seeing any more rusty candlesticks!

**Text: THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING**

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was surprising for me too. 

I attended a stop-smoking session that was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy. This happened two months and three weeks ago. I had not planned to stop smoking and didn’t really want to. I felt annoyed by the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups, and I still do. I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I said, "I won’t be trying to stop myself; it wouldn’t be fair." I thought it was reasonable because I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me pleasure. The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows.

I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge, the idea of quitting began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. Could I also achieve other things? 

In many ways, it was easy to stop. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be hard without cigarettes, but it wasn’t a problem at all. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing simple things at home on weekend mornings. 

I am starting to think that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Simplified Text:**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond positively, I know they are aware of her achievements. 

Dorothy Hodgkin deserves to be known because she made significant contributions to science. She passed away in 1994 and was a remarkable person, much like the crystals she studied. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, such as the growth of women's education and the global nature of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read biographies of scientists. A friend suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of Hodgkin and also worked in her field. However, when I went to the bookstore, I found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes for both chemistry and peace.

Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel Prize winner, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and bookstores feel the same way. This idea that scientists are less interesting than artists or writers is a common belief.

Some scientists avoid talking about their personal lives because they do not want to seem like they are promoting themselves. This can create a false image of science and may discourage young people from pursuing careers in science. However, more scientists are now appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real individuals.

The world of publishing is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and not very engaging. They often did not include much about the scientist's personal life, like their family and relationships. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been shown with their flaws, making them more relatable.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She made important discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, for which she won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964. She also helped solve the structure of insulin in 1969. Despite her busy career, she was also a devoted mother of three and had a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

There is much to learn from her life, and her scientific work is also very important. Understanding her passion for science is a challenge for biographers because many readers may not have enough background knowledge in science. However, understanding scientific ideas is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that many educated people do not recognize the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Text: Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers whose wells have dried up are now asking for her help. Along with her husband, Margaret runs a well-drilling business that uses modern tools like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she relies only on her forked hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is called dowsing. There are many ideas about how dowsing works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. One of the most believable ideas is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Some dowsers believe they can feel these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years, due to drought, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with remote cottages or barns that are now holiday homes, where it is too expensive to run water pipes over long distances. There are also golf-course developers who need water for their clubhouses.

Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She says, "You can't drill a well if there is any risk of waste getting into the water supply. The water we find is in cracks of solid rock, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. However, in Cornwall, there are many minerals, so we have to be careful about iron."

Another important factor is electricity to run the pump, which can be costly if the well is far from power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret begins her search for water. For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. "I hold the pendulum still and move it gently over the map. It will swing when it is above an area with water."

Once she has identified possible locations on the map, Margaret walks over the fields with her hazel stick. "When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation; I sway a little. When that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact spot to drill." She holds the two ends of the stick with both hands and pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is directly below, the straight part of the stick rises. It is crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water."

Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, they agree on where to drill, but if they disagree, they will keep looking until they find a common spot. Margaret is not alone in her work; many anthropologists and writers have been interested in this mysterious ability. She describes it as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this "sixth sense," it would be hard to understand how her family could continue their well-drilling business year after year.

**Simplified Text: 'We Changed Lives for a Day!'**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something different! We arranged this for four people. Here’s what happened.

**A. Amanda's Story**

I had never been in a place like this before. It was dark and noisy, with many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and I wasn't sure I could handle it! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just when I was getting the hang of it, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. I felt so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first!

By opening time at 11:30 am, there was already a line outside, and I started to feel nervous. I worried about remembering all the orders, but luckily, everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt, and I couldn’t get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say, "Pardon?" which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was completely exhausted and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn’t believe it when one of the waitresses said it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing could be. I always thought it was an easy job, but you really need to be friendly and able to handle many customers at once. I’m quite shy, and I don’t think I could manage on a busy Saturday night. I wasn’t impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich customers didn’t tip me! I was very happy to return to my children. It felt much easier than waitressing!

**B. Cindy's Story**

I was a bit nervous about being a 'mum' for a day, but I was also excited. I had been told that Amanda's daughters were cheeky, but I thought I could manage. As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I would have three hours of peace. I was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.

At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, quickly shopped at the supermarket, and took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble began. They turned the couch into a trampoline and played a game that involved screaming loudly! I thought they would tire out soon, but I was wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they wore me out! After much effort, I got them to bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew they were just trying to come downstairs to watch TV, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never realized how tiring it could be to take care of two small children. You don’t have a moment to think about yourself, and the responsibility is overwhelming. Still, I really enjoyed the day.

**C. Rosemary's Story**

On the farm, I wake up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt like a luxury! I was unsure how to dress for school. I hoped I wouldn’t stand out too much. At assembly, I looked at about 400 students and hoped I blended in. Then it was time for a math class. The children worked in small groups, which was very different from my school days when we had to recite together! I helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There is so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting and ended up helping with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (which was nice!) and then a French lesson. The children wanted to practice their French with me, which showed how rusty I was! Finally, we had Physical Education. I was exhausted, but the children had so much energy. The hardest part was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Teachers may have more holidays, but I think I will stick to farming!

**D. Hilary's Story**

I arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream, which are sold in shops and restaurants. I spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling milk containers, making ice cream, and putting on labels. It was hard not to eat some of the treats!

At lunchtime, I checked on the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and helped a sheep that had fallen over. If sheep are left for more than 12 hours after falling, they could die, so they need to be checked every day. It must be very hard in winter! After feeding the calves, I started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, every day of the year! I found it quite lonely. I missed the children because animals don’t talk back! The worst part of the job is that you can’t take time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, so it’s hard to plan any time away. Rosemary will only have about three days off this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is not steady, and I wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

**Simplified Text:**

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas. It is interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music, grew up in a rural area of southern Sweden. At the age of 30, he has become a unique trumpet player in the world. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces.

When you meet him, he looks young and energetic, just like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. A television program was also made about his work, filmed in both London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo, and his music career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet instead of a toy. This gift was a great success, and Hakan never stopped playing.

His mother found the second trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra and convinced him to give Hakan lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, recognized Hakan's natural talent right away. Hakan is grateful to have had such a passionate teacher from the beginning. Bo was very dedicated to trumpet playing and always looked for new mouthpieces.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. There will always be some imperfections, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, Hakan had a special ability to find the right balance and connect with the trumpet.

He humbly says that even as a child, his unique sound was already recognizable. Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hakan has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player.

When he was 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson wanted him to go to America, it was considered too far and dangerous. Instead, at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud agreed with Hakan’s view that playing in an orchestra was not for him, comparing it to digging in a garden.

Hakan knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after his first competition at 17 that he realized he had a special talent for connecting with the audience. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hakan prepared only the first round pieces but made it to the second round. He was lucky to know most of the pieces in that round too. However, in the final, he faced a concerto that made him nervous. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even if he felt he played poorly, people still listened to him.

Hardenberger’s honest view of his work might seem arrogant, but that is not true. He thoughtfully avoids trying to explain what makes his communication with the audience special, saying, "You risk destroying it by trying to explain. The power of music is that it can always move people."

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a powerful tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights. It is a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him takes over her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unusual friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

C. This book, which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long and quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent big success, the author has written a sequel that carries the same gentle humor and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is approaching her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her entertaining manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright spots of human experience.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can be both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what a typical workday is like for them.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and arrive at work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can last all day. There are times when I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to operate can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I’m operating, but I sometimes worry about the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it is successful, it feels amazing, which makes up for the times it doesn’t work. From 10 am to 1 pm, I see outpatients and explain the surgeries to them. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to patients. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time pressure can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I worry for the first few days about my patients, and I often dream about operating. I find it hard to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner who oversees everything, and a junior designer. My work is mostly about production, with only 10 to 15 percent being design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they agree, we create budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to ensure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people, and it’s important to communicate well. When their work comes in, I put everything together and send it to the printers. Managing several projects at once can be very stressful. Deadlines are always close, and my day is never the same. I have lunch at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to the pub. If the client likes my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but sometimes it’s 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax when I’m busy."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I wake up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet long-haul flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and just snacks during the day. People often ask me for recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, which allows me to plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. However, most are well-behaved, and I have a good relationship with my regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I need to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. Around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a local café for a big breakfast. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I have an office at home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants their garden designed, I usually set up a meeting in the evening around 7 pm or 8 pm. We focus on using old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes clients have very specific ideas, which can be challenging. However, it’s very rewarding to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can always hear the phone ringing for business. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, and I’m always tired at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows me to be creative."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. I am the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that the contractors are following the schedule and safety rules while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site workers and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on what I learn from the clerk of works.
