I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. The contractors have set meal times, so when they are eating, I can check things on site. Since we check their work, it can create tension, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but if something urgent comes up, I act immediately. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our credit card users. My job includes launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week to discuss any issues. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and go through the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that people are sharing their hard work, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album, choosing songs, a producer, and additional musicians. I also share my vision for the album with the marketing team. I manage budgets and spending. I leave work by 7:00 pm at the earliest, and most evenings I go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups in one night. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I open the mail, check the schedule for client meetings, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and helping them buy furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000, and we buy from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with restorers and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts once a month and do tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, so I work for about an hour and a half at one station, take a break for half an hour, and then switch to a different station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I often read about new air traffic rules between 12:00 am and 4:00 am. This job can be stressful, and I find it hard to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. The first thing I do is start the electronic point-of-sale system. I make sure someone is watching the cash register and coordinate lunch breaks for the staff. In the morning, I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be frustrating when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new titles for the upcoming months. I need to think about how many copies we might sell. When we want to feature a new title, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, and then I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, so I warn clients about potential problems. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second by 11:00 am, so I need to work quickly. I write the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and then make any necessary changes. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events and stay updated. I leave work around 6:00 pm, and it’s hard to relax, so I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

**A. What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps create change. Leadership is not about being tall or just being smart. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is very important, and a good leader should be able to express their ideas clearly and confidently. Dixon says it’s about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."

**B. Potential for Leadership**  
John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more potential for leadership than they think. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for good management.

**C. Good vs. Bad Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? A good leader motivates and supports you, while a bad leader makes you feel unimportant and blames you when things go wrong. The first one leads well; the second one just manages poorly.

**D. Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules, while leaders create new opportunities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes that a good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

**E. Improving Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are a boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to do it. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy to take action.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Collaboration is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their opinions, try taking the lead instead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and strive to achieve them. Look at your job demands and see where being a leader can help you succeed.

**F. Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership does not just happen; it develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don’t assume everyone will immediately accept your way of leading. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your contribution is essential and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Text: Films on Video - Film Critic Nick James Reviews Recent Releases**

A. **Abyss**  
Before *Titanic*, director James Cameron created this tense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The friendly banter and brave attitude of foreman Bud and his team remind us of tough heroes in movies by Howard Hawks. The film's design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and character development are weak. Despite the skill in making the film, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

B. **The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different view compared to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's film is more traditional, focusing on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

C. **On Guard**  
This film, loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, is a fun swashbuckler that stands out among musketeer stories. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain who causes chaos behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil, while a bit too serious for a light film, also has his moments as a swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama clichés with so much humor and charm that it doesn't matter.

D. **Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film tells a serious story. The detailed production and costumes make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is cruel when evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on the period details and not enough on the dark themes.

E. **The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly re-released video shows off director Leone's skills. The sound editing is particularly impressive, making every sound clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement back. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act ruthlessly in the post-Civil War West.

F. **The Longest Day**  
The publicity for this three-hour war epic boasts "Forty-eight International stars." With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news about the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it is best experienced on the big screen. Watching it on video does not do it justice.

**Simplified Text:**

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is indeed very interesting. The story is about a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife when she is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the outcome is uncertain until the end, with a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a strong beginning and follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the rich people of the Italian Renaissance. He gets involved in a mix of politics, church secrets, and serious murder, but we are confident he will find out who is guilty. The plot is complicated, and the book is a bit too long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective from first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who seems ready to investigate when a strange man suddenly dies in front of her. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, brave and skilled Leah is a strong character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a smart private investigator, who helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and clever, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thinking than usual. It is high-quality entertainment, as always from Parker.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, who investigate an attack and robbery at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and attention to unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock, a husband and wife team, write together. *Blood Red, Snow White* features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book combines romance, money, and violence to create an exciting suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but this time, the shift from dark comedy to farce is not as strong as his usual work.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. Canadian police are searching for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow build-up of tension and the portrayal of the smart, troubled robber make this book stand out from typical detective novels.

**Simplified Text:**

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. I have traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. I slowly realized that I was giving up my own happiness for my job. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 

I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t want to change places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship, and I don’t have strong career goals. I feel I should make the most of my freedom, at least for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind my planned schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the start of the football season?” 

Ending emotional ties makes it harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their lives and travel abroad. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that more people are realizing that adventure is possible: “People who always say, ‘I wish I had that opportunity’ are now understanding they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.”

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip. There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career when I return, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a sign of defiance!” 

For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling for a year was a time of change. “In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to change that to live well as a civilian.” There are many reasons for people my age to travel, but some common factors exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says, “Today, we have a more flexible workforce. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.” Larger companies are even allowing career breaks. “If you’ve invested time and money in training someone, it’s good to know they’ll return instead of going to a competitor.”

Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of ordinary travelers, says more thirty-somethings are reevaluating their lives. “If you’re not happy with your job—and many people aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. Now people know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t forever. Travel gives a chance to reflect and think about life.” 

Is wanting to travel just another sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. “It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, ‘Is this what I want?’” Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, believes he’s not running away. “I’m running towards something. I want to grab the things I want for myself.” But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine—going to the office every day, saying “hi” to everyone, and having coffee.

I share Ben’s worries about leaving a stable life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be going on this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so difficult. As Jennifer Cox points out, “This is common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to travel.” It may have taken a push to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll be proud to have taken this step. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Text: Plugging in at Home**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt out of touch with new technology. In this text, she shares how she changed her home into a productive workplace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized that I needed to revive my journalism career. I felt like my skills were outdated, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were common. I noticed that many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought I would have a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to use a computer for layout. I was known as the family technophobe; even using a pocket calculator was difficult for me, and I still didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.

I knew I had to act quickly to improve my skills. I thought leaving home before my children would be hard, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world of technology, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with people from around the world. The children stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

My children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous. I worried that I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. However, I learned the basic skills I needed. It turned out to be logical and easy. With practice, I improved a little each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud that I have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? In school, I always worked at a messy desk and often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. I can keep track of income and expenses using spreadsheets, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information in forums, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people worldwide.

However, there are some downsides to working from home. I can feel isolated without face-to-face contact. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the kids are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Still, many people are buying multimedia PCs not just for education and entertainment but also for convenience, avoiding the daily commute to the city.

As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called PC Usage in UK Homes describes the typical computer user: they are around 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, 32% have a CD-ROM, 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. The possibilities in cyberspace seem endless.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum look very different from the historic city of Edinburgh where it is located. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You cannot miss the new Museum of Scotland. It stands out on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with its large yellow sandstone tower and unique buildings, which are shaped like cheese wedges and have a hanging garden. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more cautious or even negative. Now that the inside is almost ready for visitors, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.

The museum does tell the story of the nation and has a timeline to help visitors understand the displays. However, it does not let its important treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and silver from Holyrood chapel, be overshadowed by national pride. The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that visiting should be a fun and visual experience, designed for everyone, even those with little knowledge of history.

Dr. Clarke is strict about what is displayed. He does not want imaginary scenes from the past, as he believes they give a false idea of history. He wants the public to see the truth. This means that what visitors see is based on what experts know. However, the challenge is whether the stories of the objects can be told clearly using explanation panels, captions, and multimedia, with only about 30 computers in the museum.

Just before the opening, it is still hard to tell how effective this will be. Some things are clear, though, like the stunning views of Edinburgh Castle. Inside, visitors will notice a series of galleries that connect to each other, each with different sizes and shapes. The walls are light-colored and designed to look like large stone blocks, with deep display cases. Natural light comes through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space where visitors can enjoy each item on display.

Thanks to a group of children aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland, the museum also has a Discovery Centre. The children wanted to be able to interact with the displays. Although they did not get that, they did create a special hands-on area for kids in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition gallery. As a result, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition. It will change every three years and features items chosen by Scottish people that have had a big impact on life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is fun, it may not address more serious topics.

Overall, Dr. Clarke is correct when he says that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it looks great from the inside and the top, but whether it fits well in its location is still up for debate.

**Text: The Future of Newspapers**

The idea of change can be both comforting and scary. Change means moving from one place to another, but the change for newspapers moving online is uncertain and difficult. Many people believe that this change will happen eventually. It is clear that print newspaper sales are falling, while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, but their online traffic keeps growing.

However, there are some surprising facts. A recent survey showed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has seen growth. News magazines, which many think would struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend is seen in books. E-readers like Kindle are becoming very popular, with sales rising significantly. Yet, when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books over the last six months, they found only a small decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that people are enjoying both digital and print formats.

The idea that young people are no longer reading newspapers is not entirely true. Recent surveys show that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, print sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.

Media experts once believed that online advertising would support the shift to digital newspapers. However, digital ad revenues are now falling, and many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to attract paying readers seems to be offering both print and digital subscriptions together. Print newspapers still play an important role in selling online subscriptions, as they generate much more advertising revenue than online ads.

Maintaining both a print edition and a website is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print newspapers still have a strong presence, and being noticed online is much harder.

**Photographing People**

People are the most interesting subjects for photography. A photo with a person is usually more engaging than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. If possible, have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their photo taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be less interesting if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don’t have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the subject can focus on something else in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it gives the impression that you are capturing a moment without them noticing.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they are a quick way to communicate feelings.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be powerful, the background can add more context. When including a background, avoid distracting details. Make sure the subject stands out against the background, which can be done by using a wide-angle lens.

**H. Interaction**  
Photos of people interacting, like talking or laughing together, can be very appealing. Look for moments of connection, such as eye contact or a friendly gesture, to capture the relationship between people.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. A slightly higher camera angle can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met briefly, a clear posed photo is good. However, family pictures can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, creating better memories for the future.

**Text: Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. Her paintings create the illusion of reality, making things look real even when they are not. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.

Not many artists choose not to sign their work, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She believes that the artwork is more important than the artist. She says, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes the interview a bit challenging at first. She admits, "I just don't like to shout about myself," and she is nervous when asked to be photographed.

After some time, Sarah becomes more comfortable, and the interview turns into a fun and interesting conversation. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she spent two years drawing at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she was not satisfied with illustration and decided to work with a specialist decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and that sparked her interest. She left to start her own business, unsure of where it would lead but feeling it was the right choice.

Sarah's skills in observation and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are very important for her trompe-l'oeil art. She often gets asked where people can learn this art, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she explains. She is always learning and believes that if you think you have mastered something, you should give up.

Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. For example, she struggles to paint bread, which she says always looks like grey concrete. She also finds math challenging. When she had a big project to paint the ceiling of a chapel, she felt confused about the measurements and thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" This self-doubt makes her view her talent in a distant way. Sometimes, she talks about herself in the third person, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"

Her trompe-l'oeil work is unique and stands out from others. She has many important projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her art is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes it look like you can enter two more rooms at the end of a hallway.

However, there is a risk with trompe-l'oeil art: once people understand the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this and says, "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination." She believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal to the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not, so she listens carefully to understand their vision.

Many of her clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working on their projects. Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They are happy with her work, which keeps her busy, even though she tends to downplay her talent. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." 

While this may be true, it is hard to get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves more recognition, and I am willing to promote it, even if she might not like it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman looks at the 'people skills' that are important for success in our jobs.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are now judged not only by our intelligence or training but also by how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired or promoted. It helps to identify who is likely to be a top performer and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future job opportunities. They focus on social skills and personal qualities, such as initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These skills are part of what we call emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For many years, these qualities were called different names, like 'character' or 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This means being able to understand and manage our own feelings and the feelings of others. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. Some people think emotional intelligence just means being nice, but it can also mean being honest and confronting difficult situations. It is about managing feelings so that we can work well together towards our goals.

C. More businesses are realizing that developing emotional intelligence is important for good management. The more complex a job is, the more emotional intelligence matters. Even if someone has strong technical skills, a lack of emotional intelligence can hold them back. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more collaborative, companies that encourage teamwork have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and customer service are key, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job.

D. Unlike IQ, which does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us succeed, especially when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for struggling organizations, nor does it guarantee success. However, if we ignore the human aspect, nothing else will work as well as it could.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has changed how we share photos. Many journalists now look to social networks for images during fast-moving events. However, some reporters have used content created by users (UGC) without asking for permission. There are guidelines that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, but there is still debate about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or take pictures of a news event, which means UGC is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure that people are fairly rewarded for their work and that permission is always asked for.'

**Simplified Text: Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many health issues, but it is especially known for helping with pain. Some general practitioners (GPs), midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly to relieve pain.

**A. What is Traditional Chinese Medicine?**  
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a visit to an acupuncturist, they will check for imbalances in your Qi by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and assessing your overall health. They will ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and your eating and sleeping habits. Acupuncturists use very thin needles that are inserted into the skin. They may also use heat from burning herbs or apply pressure to certain points to help the flow of Qi.

**B. Acupuncture Points**  
The points used in acupuncture are connected to the meridians and may not be close to where you feel pain. Many people report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done by hand or with a machine. Acupuncturists believe this sensation means the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more that are used less often.

**C. Scientific Understanding**  
Even though not all doctors believe in traditional Chinese medicine, many accept that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientists have suggested that acupuncture might work by blocking pain signals from reaching the brain or by releasing natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body called endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**  
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture as a last option. It is commonly used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Use of Acupuncture**  
Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over 2,000 years, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped some doctors outside China believe that acupuncture has real benefits. In China today, acupuncture is used in many types of surgeries, from tonsil removal to heart surgery. Needles can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with medication. While some people report little to no pain, experiences can vary. Many people might not like the idea of being awake during surgery, but acupuncturists say that acupuncture does not have the side effects of regular anesthesia, like nausea, and recovery is faster.

**F. Effectiveness of Acupuncture**  
Like many alternative therapies, it is hard to conduct clinical trials for acupuncture. However, studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists often report similar success rates. They understand that it may not work for everyone and that people respond differently. Traditional acupuncturists suggest that for long-term pain, it usually takes six to seven visits to feel significant relief, but some improvement can be felt after just two or three visits.

**G. A Different View of Pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine have different views on pain. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the specific symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the problem and looking for underlying issues in the Qi. They also consider external factors that may affect the pain, such as weather conditions. These details are important for deciding how to treat the pain with acupuncture, which is not something most medical doctors would consider.

**H. Traditional vs. Modern Acupuncture**  
Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many GPs, prefer scientific explanations. However, many traditional acupuncturists believe that using traditional Chinese medicine is necessary for deep healing, which is hard to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a clever and creative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she has a calm presence that makes her seem like she could have been a headmistress at a girls' school. However, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write in private. She believes that she can write anywhere as long as she has complete privacy.

Although she is considered one of the best crime writers in Britain, she is too modest to agree with this. Her 12 detective novels are very popular and read by millions around the world. She enjoys the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. P.D. James often reads works by women authors like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also appreciates male writers like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she thinks were the best novelists of their time.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, *Cover Her Face*, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge, where her family moved when she was 11. She met her husband there, who was a university student, and she loves the city. This is why she chose it as the setting for her book *An Unsuitable Job For A Woman*.

Her life has not always been easy. After her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill, she had to work long hours to support him and their two young daughters, Clare and Jane. Although she had many ideas for stories, she had little time to write. Thankfully, her husband’s parents helped take care of her daughters during those tough years.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then worked for 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and then in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but she was not interested in death itself. Instead, she loved the structure of writing a crime novel. 

P.D. James always enjoyed reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer. She did not want to write about her own difficult experiences, so writing detective stories felt like a good way to learn how to be a serious novelist. She realized that it was possible to follow the traditional rules of a detective story while still writing a meaningful novel about people. She believes that writing detective stories helps to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows that life is valuable, even if the person involved is not likable. She thinks that nobody truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can help decide if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered a real science in many places. Researchers believe it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can show psychological states and emotional problems. 

More companies are using handwriting analysis for job guidance and during interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to examine the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are not convinced about the value of graphology. 

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, argues that handwriting should be taken more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She states, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help determine if a person should focus on arts or sciences and whether they have a deceitful or honest character."

According to Ms. Marne, graphology can help assess possible criminal behavior: "Criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which is usually poorly shaped. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have emotional issues. This can appear as childish handwriting or in the way they write letters multiple times." 

Ms. Marne claims she can tell if people are honest or manipulative. For example, young male offenders often have very tall letters, which suggests they live in a fantasy world. Graphologists can also predict if someone might become violent, if they are under a lot of stress, or if they have psychopathic traits. Handwriting can even indicate potential suicides. 

She explains that heart and lung problems can sometimes be seen in handwriting. "You cannot make a diagnosis from just one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky. But if handwriting changes over time or becomes disconnected, it could mean something serious has happened." A strong emotional upset can also change a person's signature temporarily.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can reveal other psychological traits. For example, people whose letters connect in a thread-like way may be clever but deceitful. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing shows sensitivity and low energy. Original handwriting, which differs from standard styles, shows confidence and creativity. Disconnected writing often indicates a person who is a loner. Very small signatures suggest insecurity, while circles over the letter "i" show a desire for attention. Crossing the "t" heavily can indicate intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Ms. Marne believes it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, along with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to support graphology scientifically. She believes this will happen soon, stating, "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can reveal a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without asking them questions that they might answer incorrectly."

Despite how interesting this may sound, there is little strong evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists criticize them, saying handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the type of writing taught, and does not have any other meaning.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, does not belong to any social class, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks of it every day. This ancient habit has turned into a big business. Each stick of chewing gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the standards of the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners that help keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women especially liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and more elastic to chew, leading to the growth of a whole industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the chewing gum market has expanded, synthetic alternatives have been created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, live a difficult and dangerous life. They travel for miles to collect sapodilla in very humid conditions. The environment is dangerous, with poisonous snakes and many insects. One of the most concerning is the chicle fly, which lays its eggs in the ears and nose of the gatherers. Despite these dangers, experienced chicleros can climb a mature tree quickly to cut a path in the bark for the white sap to flow into a bag below. They must carry the liquid back to a camp, where it is boiled until it becomes sticky and is made into bricks.

Life at the camp is also hard, with a boring and often unhealthy diet based on maize, along with a local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though this work is tough, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in the entire Yucatan peninsula of Mexico.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to lower costs and meet demand. At the same time, gum producers are finding clever ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces stress (soldiers in both world wars were often given gum). The most important claim is that it helps reduce tooth decay. Plaque acid, which forms when we eat, causes tooth decay. Our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride, which protect our teeth. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to mix the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calmness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The hotel has basic facilities, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity adds to its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by chance while climbing. After a long climb down from a glacier, I was surprised to find this hotel in a stunningly beautiful and remote area. It was luxurious, with a pianist playing Cole Porter music, which felt extraordinary after a tiring day.

**C. MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the south-west of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel goes along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. The hotel is large and offers many free water sports, but you can easily find solitude on its nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the peacefulness as the sun sets.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view of the Caribbean Sea, located at an altitude of 1,000 feet. It is quiet and away from busy areas. The hotel has a colonial style, with mahogany furniture and four-poster beds covered with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a perfect escape from the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The hotel is a charming wooden building with red domes, inspired by a historic hotel on the French Riviera. Although it is a bit old, it still has a lot of charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, there is a beautiful seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with swans. This chateau, which was a family home until recently, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds and one with a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates that include breakfast, dinner, and complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Africa that avoids excessive luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers resting between safaris. Guests often decide to stay longer after seeing the beautiful gardens and cozy rooms. The hotel is located on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city center, making it a great spot to enjoy the African sunset while having a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed by the Duke of Windsor and has since welcomed many famous guests like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy visitors, but the hotel remains splendid, as its name suggests. It offers simple yet delicious food and features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her during an inspection at the Globe Hotel. Just one minute into the inspection, things are already going wrong, but the hotel staff do not realize it yet. The receptionist is busy talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue comments, "She hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She expects better from a hotel with three red stars, which means it is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for.

Before they even get a warm welcome, Sue notices that the entrance from the car park is through a door with no staff, just a buzzer, and a long, empty corridor. "This is not what I expected," she says. Things get worse when the receptionist tells them, "We have no record of your booking." It turns out that most of the hotel’s rooms are empty that night. One room is on the top floor, but Sue does not like it because it feels stuffy and has a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

When Sue started her career, people called her "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black and did not think she was very tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she reveals her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves. He looks scared when he sees her. He quickly apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge, saying, "We think there’s a blocked drain." Sue suggests that he should guide guests to another lounge instead of the one with the smell. Greaves takes notes and seems to hope that Sue's feedback will help the hotel improve.

Not everything is negative. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who shared interesting information about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner also meets the hotel’s two-rosette food rating, which makes Greaves hopeful. He asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves looks disappointed.

Sue’s job is to tell the hotel about problems that many guests might not mention. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired because he served her apple pie with his fingers. Some letters she receives include false claims about her attitude or demands for bribes. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says.

Sue must not only tell the hotel about her findings but also write a full report. The hotels pay for her advice, as there is a fee to be included in the guide. However, being recognized with red stars makes it worth it. Greaves is relieved to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. The bad news is that another inspector will return in the next two months to check if the problems have been fixed. Greaves smiles weakly and says, "We'll look forward to that."

**Simplified Text:**

Doug Scott, a mountaineer, shares his experiences of climbing the highest mountains on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While climbing Mt. Everest, Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave, 91 meters below the summit. Dougal started talking about sleeping bags with their Equipment Officer, Dave Clark, even though only they were there. Doug thought this was odd, possibly due to low oxygen levels. He began talking to his own feet, which were getting cold. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug remembered their time on the summit ridge and felt confident climbing with Dougal. He focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Mt. McKinley is known as one of the most dangerous mountains. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, they realized how difficult their task was. They followed a route from 1967 but then chose a new route to the summit. They decided to climb with all their gear on their backs, which was a new approach for this mountain. After three days, Doug's sleeping bag was wet, and they spent a tough night on a windy ridge. Because of the low air pressure, it felt like they were much higher than they actually were. Finally, they reached the summit and celebrated their success.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, they ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead after getting a free ride. They got lost in the jungles on the lower slopes, which was serious because water was hard to find. On the second day, they found some arrows painted on trees and a trail of trash that led them to a rock pool. They tried to climb a steep wall but had to turn back due to falling rocks and ice. Instead, they took the Umbwe route to reach the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca and met a guide named Phil Erscheler. Phil was leading a group up a less crowded route, and they decided to join him. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they left base camp. The Polish Glacier was icy and dangerous, so they chose to take the standard route instead. The wind was strong as they walked to the summit, and they camped outside a refuge before heading back down. At base camp, they met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits, which made Doug consider this goal for the first time.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun stays above the horizon, and the atmosphere is very refreshing. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite strong winds and very low temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although they could barely see due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg. When they arrived at Terskol, they had to pay a fee for bringing foreigners into the area, but it was later waived. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, they took a cable car up to 3,900m and then walked to a refuge at 4,200m. Two days later, they faced strong winds as they climbed. They thought they reached the summit but found there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then descended the volcano.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz, Doug and his team wanted to create a new climbing route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about possible dangers from bandits but decided to continue. On May 12, they started climbing. The weather improved, and two team members went ahead while Doug and another member climbed more slowly. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Simplified Text:**

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in many parts of our lives today, from clothing to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares some of the fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful and romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the overly frilly style, and instead choose simpler designs. Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to cut and make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening dresses in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a traditional navy-blue summer suit, which has been a staple in women's wardrobes for many years, but he makes it look fresh and new.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery design. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people wear her jewellery. Her unique style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson has been in the competitive fashion industry for just four years, but two of her handbag designs have been chosen for a major exhibition. All of her bags are handmade in the UK and are not just ordinary bags; they are stylish and glamorous, made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. A Grimson bag is special because of its elegance and attention to detail.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He believes that most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His goal is to make sure his clients look like they haven’t just come from a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, and there is a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain and top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements should be simple but strong, with fewer leaves. For wedding bouquets, she advises that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The Merrion Hotel, a new five-star hotel, has opened in Dublin after two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This project focused on what customers want and included the latest technology for both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name. However, he uses a computer system to keep track of guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special service to returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time because of its efficiency. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature in their rooms. They can change it by three degrees around the normal 18°C, and the front desk can adjust it anywhere from 14°C to 25°C.

Business travelers will find the hotel especially appealing. MacCann estimates that about 65% of his business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has created a business center in each room. Each room includes three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing equipment.

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements by laying extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy upgrades to newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished bedrooms that are welcoming.

The Merrion also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food is excellent, with Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, running the restaurant. Moving his restaurant to the Merrion has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a successful restaurant brings benefits without financial risks. With great technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to succeed.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the path that goes from east to west are full of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. 

Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." She and Danny got along well. At first, he would say some of her ideas were not worth it, but when she told him she wanted to paint those plants, he understood her vision. 

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set the whole thing up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change all the time."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't care much for garden flowers then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in their original homes, like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t cause serious trouble.

With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint, Susan has found it hard to spend time in the garden. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text:**

Many trees in the Brackham area were damaged in the strong storms that March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. The loss of these trees changed the look of the town center completely, which upset some of the local residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, he was too sick to notice. Pelham, a large and healthy man, was seriously ill for the first time in his life with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to convince him to see a doctor. He believed the police needed him and ignored her advice, trying to keep working. This made him forget things and made him short-tempered. It was only when his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor that he finally agreed to go. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, she took him to the pharmacy to get his antibiotics and then home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could hardly believe it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged and felt relieved to hear it was not. He then pulled the sheets over his head. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked, his fever went down, and he got up, that he realized the loss of the walnut tree had changed the living room's appearance. The Pelhams' large house was in a big garden. It was expensive, but Pelham had no regrets about buying it. The garden had given them privacy. Now, the storm had changed that. Before, the living room had a beautiful view of the walnut tree, which let in light but also hid the old furniture they had brought from their previous home. Without the tree, the room felt too bright, showing the worn furniture in all its bad condition. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its unattractive purple bricks and pipes. It had many upstairs windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams' every move.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. "That's what I've been saying since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Text: Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the surrounding hills that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. In the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. The wind blew strongly up there, but in our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really trouble us much. The river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, was our biggest concern. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to a dangerous level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like a small Niagara Falls, as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water poured down towards its lower parts. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream looked furious beneath the bridge. It was much deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, crashing against its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its limits. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the water began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and appreciate the great power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel that our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

**Simplified Text:**

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before that, he had done some reviews of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and radio work. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not mainly a journalist, so he was not very careful in choosing his team.

At first, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a weekly lunch to discuss which topics to cover, and there would be guests to make it more enjoyable. Mark felt like he was living a dream: a new newspaper, and he was part of the team. It seemed surprising that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even thought a rich person was helping him personally and pretending to hire him because he lacked self-confidence. The first time he saw someone reading The Front Page on the London Underground with one of his reviews, he felt very shy.

Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out as planned. They did not meet as a group, so they communicated by phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have one reviewer for each subject, so Mark decided to focus on films. Without Tom's initial support, they would not have developed the current system, where Mark writes a detailed weekly article about one film. He enjoys this way of working. He would not want to do the usual film critic job, which means reviewing every new film. That routine would make him bored quickly. He would not want to sit in a screening room on a Monday morning thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" 

The freedom he has allows him to expand his ideas or, if the week is dull, to create something interesting from little. But what is his role as a critic? He believes people choose films based on stars, advertising, or the director. Some people are loyal to certain types of films, while others avoid them. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to watch one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review is not just a guide for consumers, what is it? Mark does not feel he must be "right" about a movie. He does not think there should be a specific number of "great" or "bad" films each year. His job is to present an argument. He does not see himself as a judge, and he does not want to be one.

**Simplified Text:**

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." 

A teenager who loves sports is looking for a training partner for triathlons, preferably a girl. This is a chance to work with someone who could be an Olympic champion. The partner should really enjoy long-distance running (about 15 kilometers regularly), swimming (especially in cold water during winter), and cycling (a love for 100 kilometers is a plus). It is important to be able to do all three activities without taking a break.

Triathlons are becoming very popular in the Olympics. They attract large crowds who are amazed (and sometimes shocked) by athletes who swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers without stopping. It might be exciting for the audience, but why do triathletes push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, who does well in school, give up so much for this challenging sport?

Melanie Sears, a young athlete, has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes use when asked why they compete. She explains, "You swim 1500 meters, then run out of the water and jump on your bike while still wet. Of course, you get cold. After the 40-kilometer bike ride, you have to run 10 kilometers, which is tough when you are tired. But it’s really fun, and it’s all worth it in the end."

Melanie started competing in triathlons when she was 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior there. It felt easy, and I waved at my friends while I was racing." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not do well overall.
