"I was following a man, and suddenly we ended up at the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried while running."

But she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would end, but I am afraid that if I stop just once, I would want to stop again." Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the director of coaching for the sport. "I tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that she fell into a wall. She gave it her all, while most people stop when they feel they can’t go on. She just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but I was much slower in cycling. That’s why I am working hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents, who will pay £1,300 for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (it’s a special deal with £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, there is a cost. Her intense training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don’t have a social life," she says. "I’m not really into parties. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I do call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times in races."

Where will all this focus lead her? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750 meters, cycle 20 kilometers, and run 5 kilometers. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I don’t have anyone my age to train with," she says. It’s interesting, isn’t it?

**Text: The Collectors**

Amanda Roy writes about the things she collects and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults shares this interest. Collecting is a world of passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember this: only collect things you truly love. 

Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They were attracted to the shapes and colors of these pebbles, which were their first attempts to gather objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells just for their beauty.

I have been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by people in the past. I was fascinated by these items. 

Surprisingly, I am not alone in my interest in collecting. One in three adults enjoys this hobby. The reasons people collect have become a topic of great interest. Some believe it is the only part of their lives where they have complete control. For me, it is simply something I enjoy.

One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and artificial curiosities, like cups made from coconut shells and carved ivory beads. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, owned more than 4,000 paintings. However, you do not need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected many different items, like tulip bulbs and china cups, with great determination. 

I remember the day I convinced another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it until one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall and saw the remains of my furniture and my collection. I was not sure which loss made me sadder.

I find it interesting how collections change hands. A silver spoon that once belonged to a king or a poet gives value to items traded in markets. As small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. (Unfortunately, I threw away both the boxes and the toys!)

**My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I am in charge of creating temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic beforehand and talk to important people to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and pictures should be shown. I also ensure that the public can understand the exhibition, which involves planning interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I work with engineers and electricians to make sure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., the first thing I do is check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents need to be created to help students learn the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in school, figuring out how to make the journeys. They find the most direct routes, using the correct one-way streets and turns. I help when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different route because the road is closed. The next student must find another route, and I will give them a reason why they can’t go that way. This is to make them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I usually work on the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about the sea. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life beneath the water. This often changes their views, as it is very different from making decisions on a computer. I feel lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. However, I work for a charity, which means I always need to find more money. This makes it hard to achieve everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite varied. I ensure that our publishing program meets market needs and that we keep around 300 copies of the books we publish. We have very high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which need careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job more enjoyable. The downside, like many jobs, is that there is too much administration to handle, which leaves less time for more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**Text: A Holiday in Ireland**

Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some additions to it, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. 

The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was not a good experience because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were school friends, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers used to. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We always think it is a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she said, naming the rooms we would stay in. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband handles repairs and decoration.

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special, not just another group of guests. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt that our holiday had truly started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good.

Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play for too long because we were still tired from the journey. 

In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this would happen because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University and sees this job as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a career. She enjoys meeting successful people through her work.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By around 11 a.m., she is ready to ski and enjoys being on the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually served by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen because she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. She finds that good guests can make her week enjoyable, while some weeks are not as good.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. They often start their night at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and sometimes end at Dick's T-Bar. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sundays are her busiest days. She describes Sundays as "a frightful day" because she has to prepare breakfast for guests leaving early at 7 a.m. After they leave, she cleans quickly, strips the beds, and gets everything ready for the new guests.

If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it on Sunday. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes the new guests seem confused and have many questions. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or equipment and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but if she is too tired, she goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

Several times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press each glove using hot brass hands that looked like they had been flattened. As a child, Marie called them the "pancake hands."

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He explained, "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town, and I did too for six months when I started." 

"Have you ever been inside a tannery?" he asked. "Not yet," she answered. "You should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can help you arrange that. Tanneries are old-fashioned. The technology has improved, but they still look similar to how they did hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they found 6,000-year-old tanning tools in Turkey. The first clothing was made from animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is an expert on leather; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers really love their work."

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" he asked. "Not really," she replied. "I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." This made him laugh. She was innocent and eager to learn, reminding him of Marie, who was much taller than Rita but shared a similar bright spirit. 

"I have an idea," he said. "We will take you through the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Text: Is It a Tough Job?**

Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet us tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she often travels around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss. However, she has one small problem: she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her getting work behind the scenes. She also took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because golf is his passion. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, which usually ranges from £25,000 to £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge about the game, and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, and they made him the statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are important for TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to taste food at the best restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest subway station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop, which I dislike. I receive between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help with that."

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story brick building. Outside, there were large piles of soft sawdust. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too.

The other boys looked down from the roof, nervous but eventually one by one, they jumped and landed safely in the sawdust, smiling with relief. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. After a while, one of the boys suggested they go back up to the roof and jump down again. Although they were not very excited, they climbed back up and started jumping off again, but soon only Michael was left on the roof. The others were down below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong with you?"

Michael wanted to join them, but he hesitated at the edge of the roof, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten to jump, but he couldn't. The boys started laughing at him, getting tired of waiting. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't jump, they began to walk away, still teasing him. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called after them. 

For a long time, he stayed at the edge of the roof, looking down sadly. He was alone for nearly an hour while the sun set over the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust. He lay there for a long time in silence because the workmen had gone home. He wondered why he had been so scared to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone.

When he got home late for dinner, his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home on time by now. If you won't come home, maybe you should stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair, always patient. But Michael, feeling gloomy and miserable, hardly listened to her. He was still thinking about the boys laughing at him on the sawdust pile.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job seek help from a careers adviser. You will need to write a short history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will receive a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers, along with any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I had to remind myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the psychometric tests could show an accurate picture of me. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, but I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had not done well in the scientific and technical tests. I am sure many sick people are glad I never became a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean making a big change. Last March, after working as a marketing manager for five years, 25-year-old Donna Laney lost her job. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts for help. "Losing my job was a great chance for me to step back and look at my career," Donna says. "I wanted to rethink my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn't realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to consider the cost of retraining in design against my financial situation," she explains. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. "I decided to use my existing skills and move into a job that suited me better than insurance. I am now a Public Relations officer. I believe I would have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me understand what I really wanted to do. I have sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service."

Some people feel they would not have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services helped 26-year-old Juliet Greene make important decisions. "After working at a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I had no idea what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. I took the tests, which showed I was interested in sciences," she says. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I carefully listened to the test results and decided I wanted to study geology. I plan to start a degree course later this year. I think the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier now and more positive."

However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says, "I reached a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself," she says. "You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Text: Fun at the Dentist's**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will see bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is because they are scared." To change this, he has tried to create a place where people feel comfortable. That is why he decided not to wear a white coat, which many people connect with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable atmosphere.

This idea is surprising for many people who usually think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome explains, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past bad experiences." One of his new relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. The headsets are used during the first check-up, where the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I check their teeth. Then the headset shows a special camera that gives the patient a view of their mouth."

Surprisingly, most patients enjoy this part of their visit. Another important detail is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says, "When people walk in, I want them to feel with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make people nervous if they are afraid of dentists." I also found the pleasant smell in the office very nice.

Although he is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, Jerome takes his work very seriously. The relaxation methods are important, but the quality of treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a bit strange at first, but as long as people are relaxed, it is not painful at all.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. "One thing I learned there is that when you make it easier for the patient, it also makes it easier for you," he explains. He believes that his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards a less formal style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes over, offers him a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like a fancy beauty salon than a regular dental practice.

**Simplified Text:**

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which comes from South America, is now a huge global business worth millions of pounds. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter, which is about eight percent of all chocolate sales for the year. Only at Christmas do people buy more chocolate. 

Although chocolate production started on a large scale in the last century, the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a name that comes from a spelling mistake in the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another hundred years for the recipe to reach the rest of Europe.

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid block. A Swiss company later added milk solids to make milk chocolate.

At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French style. Then, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, which started as Dairymaid in 1905. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy qualities of milk from the English countryside, making it popular against French brands.

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain is stable at about four bars per week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are turned into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who want something different.

However, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a master in his craft. He still wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he focuses on creating beautiful objects from shells. As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely passionate, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them," he says. He never intended to sell his work, but about five years ago, some friends encouraged him to have an exhibition so more people could see his art. This led to a successful exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday, featuring 86 pieces, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes that no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him that one day, when he stops creating, everyone will want his pieces.

Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier in life because he believes he could have made even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels limited physically compared to when he began. However, his work is very different from the common shell crafts found in seaside shops. "I have a miniature mind," he says, which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own methods and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he explains. Yet, the detail and color in his work show that it is not random.

Cooke searches for beautiful, tiny shells not just on his local beaches in Norfolk, but also in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against critics who accuse him of harming the beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people walking on them much faster than I can collect them. The ones left behind are broken by the sea. I would never take shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is strong, especially considering the beauty he creates from the shells he collects.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who models and appears on magazine covers. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

I arrived at the agency and the receptionist told me that Kira would be late. I was worried because I had read negative things about models, thinking they might be difficult or vain. I wondered how late she would be—an hour? Three hours? What if she decided to go to the hairdresser instead of meeting me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to talk. 

However, when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling and relaxed, accompanied by her mother. She was not wearing fancy clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. Kira was friendly and seemed like a normal girl. Since she is under 16, she must have an adult with her when she works, and her mother looked proud of her.

Kira seems a bit confused by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter the modeling competition. Kira initially said no, but her sister sent in some photos anyway. When Kira learned she was a finalist, she was at school. This achievement gave her the confidence to continue, and she won easily. The Select model agency in London offered her work right away.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to balance her two lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not kind. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle because she is not arrogant. She explains, "They think that because I became a model, I can't be the same person. The only thing that has changed is that I am more confident, but not in a bad way."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day. She cannot make plans with her friends because she does not know her schedule. However, her friends understand and do not complain about her modeling.

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I finish the interview, I ask her what she would like to do if she didn't have her beauty. She thinks for a moment and replies, "I would like to do what you are doing."

**Simplified Text:**

Father and son start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. The father and son team—one is an explorer and the other is a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool.

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt,' an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to explore. Since they first cleared the land and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent the last ten years getting permission to work from the landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They have dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have a few people we can contact."

As news spread through the valleys about their dig, the excitement of gold began to attract the attention of local people as well as gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are cautiously hopeful. "It would bring more people here if they are right," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if these two find gold, I hope millions of people do not come and damage the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands of people worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**Text: IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is a problem and they need to get to the top quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. Rachel adds, "No one's tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a very pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They traveled five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic to a site with many underwater volcanoes, where black smoke comes out of the chimneys. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This water flows out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.

Rachel recalls a frightening moment when she first dived with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. She heard a huge bang as shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them." After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

Text: "I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by foreign train schedules, money, and languages. 'Never again,' I said as I returned home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I needed was one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a regular bed; the train's movement rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree way of traveling is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where common sense can be forgotten along with your paperback book and socks. All you need is one of those tickets in your hand. 

A system that lets young people travel through many countries in one day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize how much we could do with this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too exciting; there was always another country just over the border. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We planned our own schedule and focused only on the sights we could easily see. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like most other Inter-Railers who shared train corridors, food, money, and music with us. 

The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not let you discover new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is large, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to realize this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away."

Text: 

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage has been left behind can be very disappointing. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and stuck in clothes that are not suitable for the weather. 

Airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, but it is common for travelers to experience this problem at some point. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it is not always possible for them to ensure that your checked luggage travels on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes during your journey. 

The system works like this: Airlines require passengers to check in early, which gives enough time for bags to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to transfer between flights, and these times are also extended to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which can cause problems with luggage handling. 

Human error can also happen, such as when a destination label gets torn off a bag. These issues can be worse at large airports, known as 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million of them changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to transfer between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). 

Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The chance of losing luggage when changing planes is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers make quick connections to Latin America. 

To avoid losing your luggage, try to book direct flights whenever you can and check in early. If you must change planes, it is best to fly with the same airline for all your flights. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers. 

If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and various yellows from the sunlight, creating a calm atmosphere like the gentle sounds of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, almost like a flash of light, and it is gone in an instant. However, its image stays in your mind, and its impact is much greater than its small size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He feels a strong connection to this little bird, but he cannot explain exactly why. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess that turned into a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this story. Even though kingfishers have many shades of blue, they do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, making them appear blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the angle of the light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. Their beautiful colors and the fact that they can be watched from a distance make them fascinating. Charlie James's first hideout was an old blanket he put over his head while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird returned within minutes and sat just one meter away. However, it took him four more years to take his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream where kingfishers lived. Unfortunately, school took away some of his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant to the editor and eventually became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film. "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his relationship with the kingfisher than what his work can show.

**Text: Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She ended up filling in for an absent assistant and was later asked to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous. I have always felt good about standing in front of an orchestra." Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after trying twice before. Looking back, he feels lucky about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I would have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and a role as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he finds it hard to shake off the "competition" label: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be worried." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. If this doesn't happen, his career could suffer.

**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of attention," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much bigger people, which makes a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many arguments, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I tried my best to achieve the performance I wanted. People respect my skills as a musician. I learn from every experience I've had, both in musical style and performance. Now, I will do whatever people ask to discover what I enjoy."

**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and told his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall soon found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He had to manage some relaxed professional musicians who were reading newspapers during the show: "I was firm with them. I always gave a clear beat and aimed for the best result. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need advice from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse. I have never studied conducting formally, and no book teaches you how to conduct, but people have been kind to me. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are thinking about taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island would be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, my husband Steve and I were ready to leave, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere and better scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought our son Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still felt there was more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes shut, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also great fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides isn’t boring. It was very clean, and the staff were wonderful. On one ride, I couldn’t sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to sit with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am not very brave, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave enough. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it too easy, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we definitely felt that way. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the main attraction, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even worse! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were going home early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine moved from London to the countryside when her children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband suggested she start a computer-aided design business. It was challenging at first and required a lot of money. However, she was careful with her spending and kept the bank informed. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business remains small, and most customers pick up their work instead of having it delivered.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but after moving to the countryside, she decided to start her own business. She creates a range of 50 greetings cards that she sells to museums. Maggy works in a large room upstairs. One downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She does not advertise her business; instead, customers hear about her through word of mouth. Although she misses sharing ideas with others, she believes the benefits of working alone outweigh the drawbacks.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when it was growing. In two years, her earnings increased from £24,000 to £80,000, and she employed six full-time workers. However, due to a decline in the economy, she had to let them go, which was difficult because jobs are hard to find in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and works with women who also work from home. Delia knows she must lower her prices when needed and look for new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** manages her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the area. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she often takes calls at unusual hours. The challenge is staying disciplined and closing the office door when needed. She publishes children's books from different cultures and collaborates with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home. Interested in health, she began making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Friends and family started asking for cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, and now she has a baker and an assistant. Meg no longer bakes herself, as she focuses on managing the business. Her biggest challenge has been the financial side, as she did not have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are teachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered a school nearby that offered evening classes in instrument making and attended for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John finally made his first cello, which Paul loved. John has now retired from teaching and works full-time as a craftsman, making about twelve violins each year. One of his violins was even sold to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers climbing up to play the piano as soon as he could. Although their dad wanted Paul to play the violin, Paul was more interested in the cello player in his dad's music group. He took cello lessons and really enjoyed it. Huw, on the other hand, did not want to play the violin.

Huw, now 22, is becoming a successful pianist and composer. Paul has achieved great things with the cello his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. He played his father's cello until recently when he borrowed a 304-year-old cello from the Royal Academy of Music.

Paul will soon perform on television with his new cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He believes that even though the piece has a famous history, he will play it in his own style. However, he will not be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. "You are always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies," he explains. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training. 

Gareth says that working on the farm helps him understand the farmers' problems. "I can talk to them on the same level," he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and repairing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers picking flowers and collecting butterflies when he was younger. Now, he wonders where he would find those flowers and nests. He realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but he believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government advice.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Both sides wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. "We are at a crossroads, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," Gareth says. 

Gareth's work includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to make sure tasks are completed efficiently and without too much trouble," he explains. He enjoys seeing projects finished, but he spends about half his time on reports and paperwork.

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys talking to the public, although he finds some people's attitudes frustrating. "Some visitors come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it," he admits. "Being polite to those people can be annoying!" But, as Gareth says, it all comes down to common sense. 

If you have plenty of common sense and like outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day as she prepared for the World Championships next month. She had taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. 

I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that's all." 

Kendra said, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I have a strict schedule to get fit." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It's important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. There will be more pressure because of the home crowd. People expect us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra warns that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard not to win," Kendra says. "But once the game is over, we become friends again." 

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It is important that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. "As captain, I believe I should have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my team."

Kendra adds, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents help a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be difficult to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents may not realize their child's needs until they show frustration through difficult behavior. While most schools can support children who excel in academic subjects, musically gifted children often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is not a priority there. 

Children who are musically talented, and those whose abilities are encouraged by their parents or teachers, may benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established recently. These schools create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend about one third to one half of their day on music activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), playing in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program that focuses on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with small class sizes and a high number of teachers compared to students. Most children at these schools live there full-time, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. One major issue is the cost; fees can be high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for boarders). Each school tries to help parents of gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They emphasize that their goal is to help children become well-rounded individuals.

It is important to note that separating musically gifted children from their peers at an early age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, all specialist schools monitor their students closely and provide help when needed.

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic program, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a regular school with a strong music program or by combining a normal school schedule with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be available for families living far from London or other major cities.

**Text: An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is well-known for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house provides many of her subjects. It is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower borders along the path that goes from east to west are full of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood what I meant."

Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants instead of painting the whole garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days, and then I bring in another one to add to the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also finds beauty in the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they keep changing."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I wasn't really interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake, like silk or plastic ones sold in shops. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they seem just as comfortable in her garden as they do in their original homes, like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of subjects to paint right outside her door, it has been hard for her to find time to work in the garden. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Text: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. She works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She sees being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. "It's a good way to meet successful people," she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds the least enjoyable part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she explains. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks are not as good for various reasons," she adds.

Sarah lives in a chalet with her friends, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. They often start their night at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day when you don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired," she says. 

On Sundays, she starts work earlier, with breakfast for guests ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast, stripping beds, and getting everything ready for the new guests. If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or equipment and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Text: Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper who spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. I first went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and I felt rushed here when I could be quietly with an animal. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking about how I usually clean cages or handle rats. I find it interesting to see how magazines work, but I really enjoy my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I was dirty but had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn’t expect gardening to be so physically demanding or require so much planning. I am more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint doing some tasks, but I was surprised that it didn’t bother me. The friendship among the nurses was great, and it felt very different from my usual male work environment. I feel my job is less important compared to nursing. My day at the hospital was not pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**A. Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past some beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning trip.

**B. Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**C. Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am very grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I thought was wonderful. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since.
