The journey was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**D. Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to wait for a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train finally arrived, many people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**E. Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains when they are young, but that’s not my case. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had taken care of. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

**Text: 'Getting Published: Advice for Writers'**

Are you trying to get your story published? If you are unsure where to send it, our expert Margaret Stubbs can help. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" 

First, you need to research the market and learn about publishers. It is also important to practice your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires knowledge about the publishing world. No matter what type of writing you do, you should understand the markets you want to reach. 

One of the best ways to learn about these markets is to read as much as you can. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are currently accepting. Remember, this knowledge needs to be updated regularly because new publications come out all the time, and editors may change jobs or focus on different topics.

If you are unsure about what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories, as this market is quite limited today. Get recent copies of these magazines and see what types of stories they are buying. Pay attention to who their readers are, as these readers have specific expectations, and the editor wants to meet those needs.

Writers often ask me, "This story has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I never want to discourage anyone. However, it is likely that the work is not yet ready for publication. Many new writers are too eager to send out their work before they are prepared. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. This is rare. When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have years of experience in publishing or journalism before achieving it.

When you finally send out your work, keep writing more stories while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of giving up on your stories, work on improving them. 

In the beginning, I recommend not sharing your work with others. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before finding success. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.

**Text:**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I expected. The usual clean and bright feeling of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and many college students had left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different people. He looked well-off with his tanned skin, nice sweater, and soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came to a girl near me, who had long blond hair. I thought about talking to her too. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She replied, "I’m going north, but to New York." He thanked her and moved on.

Now, I was paying close attention. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but when she said she was going to Wilmington, he just walked away. I moved closer, pretending to look at the platform. I was going to Philadelphia, and I understood why he didn’t ask me. He probably thought I looked unreliable. He quickly glanced at me and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed and asked a woman reading a book, "Please tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She looked up and said, "Yes, I am."

"Could I ask you a favor?" he said. I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell the woman was becoming cautious. The man noticed too and said, "I promise it’s nothing too difficult!" They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, pulling their wheeled bags behind them.

The man explained, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, went grocery shopping, and came home to find my wife upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia, not knowing what to do." The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where this was going. 

"So I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport." I thought it was strange he didn’t go himself if it was so urgent. The woman asked, "Why don’t you go yourself?" He replied, "I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." I thought this was a weak excuse. I looked at them again. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a plain one, which seemed odd. It looked stapled shut too. I thought to myself, "Be careful, lady."

**Text: 'Gary and Me'**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes that everyone has a chance in life. His chance was to run a restaurant, and Gary's chance was to cook. When John found out about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was just what he wanted.

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembers being sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. Because of this, he wanted to make time for family. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made sure to have meals together. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which gave him plenty of money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John was happy to see Gary working.

Although Gary was not very good at school, he excelled in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could prepare over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would pursue a career in catering. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.

Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time, saying, "If you chase two hares, you catch neither." John also told Gary that he needed to achieve his goals by age 30, or it might be too late.

At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats, finishing his work in an hour. He even helped others with their tasks. John is amazed by how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become and feels very proud of him. He has always taught Gary that hard work is necessary to achieve anything because no one gives you success for free. Gary has recognized the opportunities he has and has taken full advantage of them. John believes that as children grow up, they may only remember a small part of what their parents say, but he is happy that Gary seems to have listened at times.

**Text: Finding a Flat in Dublin**

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult. The best way to find one is through personal contacts. If you know someone who knows someone else who is moving out, that can help. But if, like Jo, you have just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have any contacts to help you find a place. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin felt very unfamiliar. She felt nervous when she took the train to start her new job there. She didn’t question why she was going; everyone at school expected her to leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and experience life. Some of her classmates had moved to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family members helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.

Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel permanently. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because they are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. However, Jo didn’t know they were still talking about her while she answered an advertisement for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her workplace and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice and that the people living there would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.

There wasn’t a long line for this flat because it was more about finding a "Third Girl Wanted" than just a flat to rent. The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs, and as Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she told Jo. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."

Jo asked, "What do you mean?" The girl replied, "She didn’t have to do anything. She just looked around and acted like it was terrible in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline, who had colorful clothes and bright hair, was a punk. Jo was surprised because she had seen punks on the street but had never talked to one before. 

"I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa, the girl with the college scarf, invited Jo to have tea with them. She brought out three mugs: one with 'Nessa', one with 'Pauline', and one with 'Other' written on it. "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," Nessa said kindly.

**Text: Behind the Dolphin's Smile**

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, according to the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of dolphin populations.

Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, sensitive to human feelings, and they inspire us with dreams of freedom in the ocean. Our affection for dolphins has been supported by TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today.

The population of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by law and cared for in special marine reserves. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.

There are forty different types of dolphins around the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen only in small groups. We know very little about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises were once often seen near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and used to be found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, including the Thames. Now, they can only be found in small numbers in the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress, such as skin injuries.

It is hard to understand exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is reducing fish populations and threatening local fishing industries, which also puts dolphins and porpoises at risk. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are removed from one area, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. Many modern fishing methods use large nets that are either left floating or pulled quickly through the water. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died after being caught in these nets.

Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in their fat. Female dolphins produce milk that contains these poisons, which can harm their young. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.

Another serious threat to dolphins comes from human activities. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their environment. Noise pollution from ships and oil drilling travels much better in water than in air, which may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**Getting Fit**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to. 

Exercise helps improve your muscle tone and can quickly change your body shape. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you maintain good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It can also prevent muscle imbalances that might lead to injuries. Additionally, exercise can improve specific areas like your thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You may have heard these benefits many times, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some medical conditions. 

If you still need convincing, just remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure about what exercises are right for you, it’s a good idea to talk to your doctor.

Good posture is essential for improving your body shape. If you have poor posture, it can make you look and feel less energetic. To improve your posture, imagine that a helium balloon is pulling the top of your head up towards the sky. This can help you lift your chest and breathe better, while also making your body look slimmer.

Stretching is also important. It helps improve flexibility and makes it easier to move. Stretching can prevent injuries caused by overuse. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. 

A good exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**

What keeps filmmakers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman away from their homes for months? They are searching for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be very hard to find them. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost constant rain, causing many problems. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Their teamwork has produced some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a popular film about leopards. While this film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.

Traveling filmmakers have been exploring the world to film exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman during one of his rare meetings with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have occasional arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither of them sees themselves as the leader, and they get along well because they both view the animals in a similar way. 

"When we are moving, we have to set up our tents each night. But this time we are staying in a more fixed camp. We set out at 5 a.m. each morning, so we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a vacuum flask." Their daily meals consist of pre-packed food that is heated and served by whoever is available. "It's not unusual for us to be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be stressful," says Newman. 

It can be a tough life, but being in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions, where one lioness would often go off alone. When she returned, she would greet all the other lions and even came to greet their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in the field to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. 

"Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the beginning," says Newman. "We share the same ideas and vision. We aim to create a film that captures the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is much better than just appealing to their minds."

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, which is normal for her as she prepares for the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then had a training session in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to learn about her training location. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but she knows they will be a tough team to play. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra warns that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra says. But after the game, everything changes. "We are all friendlier after the match."

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It is important that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it is essential to have a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."

Kendra has planned her netball career carefully from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she is likely to have tears in her eyes, knowing her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**Text: In Hot Water**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she gets into a small steel vehicle for underwater exploration and dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.

Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "Space is very limited. I can reach out and touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface."

"If there is a problem and we need to get to the top quickly, we can hit a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface. No one has tested it yet, but I don’t think it would be a pleasant journey."

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were testing how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. "We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There is a large area of underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It pours out at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."

"The only time I was scared was during my first dive with the Americans. We were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we were so relieved - we were still alive!"

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I finally saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling."

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, and how we speak, including our speed, volume, and tone of voice, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce wanted to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she noticed a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing but decided it would make her late, and she believed being on time was very important. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who worked at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will she be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that candidates who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. People often think that what is inside matters most, but in an interview, it is important to present yourself well. However, many people overlook the importance of a professional image.

For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her that she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work performance should matter more than her appearance.

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message about feelings comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. Therefore, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview. She was offered the job immediately. However, she was too enthusiastic about the offer. Once her boss saw how excited she was, he offered her a lower salary than she expected. She believes she could have negotiated a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.

Finally, what we say and how we say it can affect the success of an interview. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, the annual report can provide information about the company’s activities. Mentioning an area that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.

Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and highlight important points."

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring and no one was enjoying their work anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start my farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, about 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very surprised when I told him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' Most people my age need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but luckily, many of them still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were terrible. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people thought I would get bored, but that never happened. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed, but I miss socializing with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He shares, "I was in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I didn’t find the work rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I decided to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then, I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, which is the best part."

**Text: Dedicated to Their Sports**

Four young athletes share their experiences.

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football team, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest achievement was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training can be expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It’s fun there with great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics—that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I often see the same people at competitions. Professional surfers take their sport seriously, and the best waves are usually at dawn, so I have to skip late-night parties. I don’t mind too much, but I do enjoy sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. Winning the championship also led to me hosting a surfing series on TV, so I guess I’m a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When five guys are on a boat together, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we don’t seek media attention. Sometimes reporters seem more interested in our celebrations than our race results. I spend eight months a year away, so it’s nice to come back and hang out with friends from different backgrounds. You can’t focus on the sport all the time; it’s not healthy. I am known in sailing, but I rarely get recognized in public. I wouldn’t want to be a celebrity. I do receive nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to each one, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd’s support. At my last tournament, it got a bit overwhelming with so many people around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I’m out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend didn’t like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that’s part of why we broke up. It was tough, but sacrifices are necessary in sports; you have to be serious and professional. I try not to let it bother me too much. I want to focus on my game now and enjoy life more after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food. If children only learn about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The main goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. So even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she is patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are sometimes inconsistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy him sweets because we say they are bad for him, but we are buying double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on my mood. If I’m feeling good, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers, making up for the difference.

**Text: Five-Star Luxury and Modern Technology**

The Merrion Hotel, a new five-star hotel, has opened in Dublin after two years of work converting four large 18th-century houses. This project focused on what customers want and allowed the hotel to use the latest technology for both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know guests by name. However, he uses a computer system to keep track of guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special services for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to install, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time because of its efficiency. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature in their rooms. They can change it by three degrees around the normal 18°C, and the front desk can adjust it anywhere from 14°C to 25°C.

Business travelers are a significant part of the hotel's market, making up about 65% of guests. To meet their needs, the hotel has created a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing facilities. 

Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements by laying extra cables. They rent televisions instead of buying them, allowing for easy upgrades to newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed. Despite all this technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished rooms that are welcoming.

The Merrion also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food is excellent, with Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moving his restaurant to the hotel. This change has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a successful restaurant brings benefits without financial risks. With great technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to succeed.

**Text: Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully to share how they find their energy.

A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to be challenged and learn new things. Right now, I'm learning flamenco dancing, which is very energizing. If I'm bored, I feel drained. Being effective, even in small ways, gives me energy."

B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. Work is not a burden for me. I need enough sleep to feel good. When I only get six hours, I feel tired. Exercise helps me, but I have to find the energy to do it! I do yoga once a week and try to work out at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it's good to eat something then."

C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat healthily for energy; I think it comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I dislike negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I’m surrounded by lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos and writing fun song lyrics during my travels."

D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in being positive about life. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Communicating with others gives me energy—just smile at someone and see how it feels when they smile back. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."

E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a garden, which was more energizing than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing also gives me energy. I enjoy sneaking into nature, and if caught, I act surprised and say I didn’t know it was private."

F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you need to be interested in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things I don’t want to do drains my energy. I used to be on many committees, but I didn’t like the demands on my time. You have limited energy, so focus on what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones, which were used until iron skates appeared in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the wealthy people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but everything changed at the 1924 Winter Olympics when 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating very popular.

Today, ice skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and physically challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. Your body position is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees relaxed, leaning a bit forward. Relaxation is crucial in skating, more than in many other sports.

To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot while making a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you practice this for a while, you can gradually make longer movements as you gain experience. Learning how to fall safely is one of the first skills a skater should master. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall without getting hurt, stay relaxed to reduce the impact with the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.

Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. The best way to start is by learning figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer good guidance, so you can quickly learn the basic moves, and soon you will be able to do turns, jumps, and spins in freestyle.

If you watch skilled skaters, you will notice how relaxed they are and how smoothly they move. To achieve this, it’s important to follow a regular exercise program. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also boosts heart and lung health and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it creates a great fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

If there is one thing that can make you cry with happiness, it is seeing a talented child receive a medal. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the joys and challenges of their lives.

A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The training is very hard right now. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I try to take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."

B. **Annika's mother**: "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I have seen some parents push their children, but that doesn’t work. To perform at Annika's level takes a lot of time and energy, and you have to want to do it. People often say that we, as parents, have sacrificed a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."

C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at the age of ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents enjoy show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love the excitement and fun of show-jumping. Even if my parents weren’t involved, I would still do it because I am very determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

D. **Sarah's mother**: "From the moment Sarah first sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she had found her passion. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the living area of our horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is completely happy on a horse and knows what she is doing. Watching your child succeed at something they love is an amazing feeling."

E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t focus as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about becoming arrogant; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."

F. **Jane's mother**: "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father said, 'Let’s see if she likes it.' He had tried to teach me chess when I was young, but I found it boring. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I am proud when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors looked. According to Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago.

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture started, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories we eat. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers began farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a good food, it caused health problems. Farming spread because one piece of land could feed many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it also brings challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, the standard bed length has stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products often. The question is: how tall can we get? 

Some scientists believe we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, there is a twist. While individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate has warmed, we have become thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If global warming continues, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by climate change.

**Text: Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we see people getting excited on game shows, we often wonder who they are. 

Some people think that studio audiences are the least important type of audience. I have heard that even people who work in television do not respect them, comparing them to cattle. I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people wanting a moment of fame. However, there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract various types of people for different programs.

Many of us who watch television at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit through hours of waiting just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to appear on television for a moment. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said, "I came for a chance to be on TV." Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."

Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh when told. This may be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We believe a show should be good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte enjoyed being part of live television. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors; I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a studio monitor.

Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most of the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Simplified Text:**

**Favorite Places**

**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes that have no human touch. I prefer places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the high hills, quiet valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. This was my first attempt at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than the regular ticket. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we passengers see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a deckchair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a small train carriage, looking into other people’s homes. I like the ordinary landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look more closely and find something new.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors prefer to enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into beautiful valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is perfect for hiking. There are not many people living there and not many visitors. It is a quiet and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and since then I have visited every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she had found a beautiful pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I replied, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could admire it and look it up in our natural history book.

I got home late and quickly started boiling some water when I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I rushed to their bedroom. The problem involved our cat, Domino, and a white mouse named Bianca, which I had received as a Mother's Day gift. Domino was running around the room with the mouse in his mouth, trying to escape and enjoy his catch while avoiding the children who were waving their arms.

In the chaos, I tripped and fell. As I was thinking about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved, while the kids and the cat were jumping around in a loud, chaotic scene. The dog was barking, and the pot in the kitchen boiled over. I quickly turned off the gas and returned to the chaos with renewed energy. 

I managed to grab Domino by the tail and rescued the small, wet mouse from his jaws. Interestingly, this same mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life before dying of old age. 

Feeling encouraged, I looked at the snake to find a way to catch it, but it seemed impossible. In the end, I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, rocking back and forth. Slowly, the snake relaxed and rested its head on its body, but it still looked suspicious. I carefully placed my hands under the snake and stood up, then walked to the end of the garden. I wanted to give the snake a chance to live freely, so I pointed it towards a nearby tree.

When I finally let go of the snake's head, expecting it to attack me, it instead slid over my shoulders like a colorful shawl, making itself comfortable. We stood there in the fading light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, broke the silence with a scientific comment: "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." 

I asked the children to help encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did, climbing up the wall and disappearing over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said what we were all thinking: "Boy, that was one big snake!"

**Text: 'Drop Me a Line!'**

In our fast world of phones, faxes, and computers, the old art of letter writing is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by any other way of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and pleasure in reading its contents.

Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote, and I loved receiving his long, funny letters. Most letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.

I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch through letters. Writing letters actually helped our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than by speaking.

I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a whole year’s worth of news! I especially love receiving letters in airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I get letters from friends in different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. There’s also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant after a holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited her home twice, and she has stayed with us.

My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long. The local newspaper even wrote about us on the front page!

I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Simplified Text:**

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being slowly destroyed. Scientists and researchers are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not survive for future generations. The mountain is believed to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include pictures of cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.

Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues at this rate, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. "When people can't take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer," he explains. "The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and visitors can't see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look fresher."

Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this is not done, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be affected.

Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may be effective, it will also cause protests from local people." He reminds us that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea isn't perfect. Our department believes the best solution is to let people visit the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would prefer that everyone could see it, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee, as there seems to be no chance of government funding."

In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also researched the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—since tourists can now avoid the long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Text: Young Shoppers**

Shopping in supermarkets with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother explains, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the latest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. I hate saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave home. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I feel stuck."

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they are in a supermarket. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on television. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things, and arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth are not convincing when compared to attractive ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is important for parents and children to talk about food. If children only learn about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they are competing with the advertising industry and often have to disappoint their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV advertising, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy products. However, Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to persuade people to buy something. Even if they cannot say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."

Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when discussing food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests: "My son pays attention to ads but is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."

Parents also admit they are not always consistent in their responses to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Although parents might spend less if their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers, making up for the difference.

**Text: Climbing Walls**

In the past, climbers went to mountains to climb. Now, people can enjoy climbing in many places, both indoors and outdoors. The audience watches closely as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by just two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common: The Wall. The ability to hold these events is thanks to new technology that is developing quickly.

Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on natural cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to train on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom.

Soon, many sports centers began to build climbing walls using special bricks designed for climbing. One of the first climbing walls was built by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Throughout the 1970s, many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls, but they had some problems. These walls were only vertical, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once built, the walls could not be changed, and climbers would eventually get bored with the same routes.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a new material that could be shaped like the holds found on cliffs. These holds could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French manufacturers also started to create climbing panels on steel frames. Unlike heavy concrete, steel frames could be built anywhere as free-standing structures. This system allowed climbers to have many different holds to choose from, giving them endless options for climbing.

**Text: 'So You Want to Be an Actor'**

If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably mention that it is a risky career. Acting is indeed risky because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some people you thought were your friends might think you are making a bad choice, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. Ultimately, it is a personal decision, and you are responsible for your own choices and dreams.

There are no easy paths to becoming an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee that you will succeed in the profession. Success often depends on a mix of luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes good pay.

Many people ask what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination, with imagination being the hardest to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. 

Where does the desire to act come from? It can be hard to explain why you want to act. In theater, the important moment is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. 

When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often do not have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they do not take anything for granted. They understand that their success depends on their current job, and fame can be temporary. 

Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs like selling clothes or waiting tables. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. However, even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid discussing their chances of success. They find ways to cope with the stress of competing for roles and the fear of rejection. No one likes to be rejected, and this possibility exists from the moment you start auditioning. You are saying that you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, your success depends on how much you care about acting; if you don’t care, others may not care about you either.

**Food for All**

We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available. 

A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She also understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a key reference for modern cooks. It offers simple but expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes that are not boring. Recently updated, it answers the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"

B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to owning the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. To go along with his first TV series, "Blanc Mange," he has released a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that good cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book includes over 80 amazing recipes that illustrate his points. It is a practical guide that explains why some dishes can fail and introduces basic food chemistry. Monsieur Blanc enjoys cooking for others, and this book shows that he is very good at it.

C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students of all levels to achieve perfection. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have published a new book, "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which features 100 respected recipes from the school. Although the recipes are classic, they still feel fresh. While Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking, it has also changed its approach to reduce rich, creamy sauces and calories. The book starts with basic kitchen procedures and includes chapters on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe is illustrated with step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools worldwide have chosen a recipe they are famous for and shared their secrets.

D. Fast food? Many people think it means bad food that takes a long time to cook. However, Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes that people want tasty food when they come home tired and hungry. He thinks it is possible to make something delicious in the same time it takes to order a pizza. In this new book, you will find over 200 recipes from around the world, each ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way, and his recipes are simply delicious. If you doubt that fast food can be great, try his recipes!

Text: 

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher jokingly asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by about one centimeter. More tall people are being born, but this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how our ancestors were. We are starting to lose the effects of poor diets from the past. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are beginning to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

For most of human history, our ancestors had a varied diet. Women gathered fruits and herbs, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. However, about 9,000 years ago, agriculture began, which changed everything. Farmers took over many green areas, and now just three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This limited diet has harmed our health. 

In Ohio, scientists found that when healthy hunter-gatherers started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Although corn was thought to be a good food, it caused health problems. Farming spread because one piece of land could support many more people than hunting could. 

Today, many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets starting to reflect the variety of our ancestors' diets again. As a result, the average height of men is now 179 cm in the US, 180 cm in Holland, and 177 cm in Japan. This is a positive change, but it comes with challenges. 

Even though people are getting taller, some things have not changed. The standard bed length has been 190 cm since 1860. Legroom in planes and trains seems to have gotten smaller, and clothing companies are always adjusting their sizes. The question is: how tall can we get? 

According to Robert Fogel from the University, we might reach a height of 193 cm this century. However, scientists warn that while individuals may be growing taller due to better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and shorter, even when well-fed. If the planet continues to warm, we might shrink even more. In other words, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**A NEW LIFE**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring and no one was enjoying their work anymore. I didn’t plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn’t get a great pay-off, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel restaurant. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, about 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he makes a living as an artist. He explains, "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to take redundancy and become an artist. The career counselor I spoke to was very surprised when I told him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' Most people my age need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we took a risk and moved to northern England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends behind, but we’ve been lucky; many of them still visit us."

**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and paid well, but the hours were terrible. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people thought I would get bored, but that has never happened. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always collections and new designs to work on, so I keep a strict schedule. I feel happier now and less stressed, but I miss socializing with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I take the blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when your name is on the product, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He shares, "I was in finance from the age of 22, making deals. I enjoyed the excitement, but I didn’t find the work fulfilling. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I decided to resign and travel for a year. During that time, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and spoke to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then, I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life, and that is the best part."

**Text: A Successful Game**

Two brothers are discovering that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and enjoying their childhood memories. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played the game and, as Dave says, "had the best time ever."
