Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico, but they continued to play pichenotte with the board that Grandpa made from old wooden crates.

When visitors came over, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed that the old pichenotte board was cracked and decided to make a new one. The new board was beautiful. A relative saw it and wanted one, and then a friend wanted one too. To see how much interest there was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. "People started to watch," says Dave, "and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon they sat down, and before long, they couldn't get up from the table!"

When people asked about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found that the game likely started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game was adapted into 'squails' in British pubs, and British people brought it to Canada a century ago. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. 

Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' that they flick across a wheel-like board using their finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points, while three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. There are also eight small posts that act as obstacles. The game usually lasts about two minutes.

After seeing how popular the game was at the bar, the Lagasse brothers made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Soon, championships were held, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards sold quickly, and the brothers decided to start a pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and began making boards. They have produced more than 450 boards so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12 kg and is 1 cm thick. Norm explains, "They're very durable because they need to handle a lot of use." They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website.

Currently, there are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game. However, the day may come when the brothers' garage will be home to a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that just a few years ago, this area was a piece of waste ground, flat and covered with brambles. For a long time, it was seen as useless land. However, with careful planning and hard work from one man, supported by his wife, this land has been transformed into the beautiful place you see today.

Many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat area into the lovely landscape you see now. Although machines like bulldozers helped, a lot of hard work was also done by hand. Once the land was shaped, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 

In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted. These plants were carefully chosen to survive in the salty air near the sea and to withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to use these materials, but soon he became an expert himself.

You will notice that all the models are built to the same scale and that great care has been taken with even the smallest details. This was achieved through patience and special building techniques. The Model Village has become a popular attraction, known for its high-quality work and maintenance. The methods used to create these realistic models have been used in other model villages in England and have even been taught in some college courses.

All the buildings in the village show traditional British architectural styles and are not based on any one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. As you walk around the village, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini-golf course, which is the newest addition.

We ask you to stay on the paths during your visit and not to touch any of the models; even a small mistake can lead to hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome on a short lead.

To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these buttons to see the models operate. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if there are any models that you think need improvement. We are constantly updating the models and need your feedback.

We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

**Simplified Text:**

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do pose for paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. More often, serious harm is done to public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people report these issues to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle such problems. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel—a place where people expect privacy—she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. 

The PCC should also look into a recent shocking story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these shameful attacks? This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers, which would be reported by other media. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to afford to hide and take pictures of celebrities without their consent.

If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be several challenges. How would it decide whether to start an investigation? Should it contact the victim and encourage them to complain? If the person still refused to act, should the PCC proceed anyway? Celebrities and royals might expect that any story about them would be investigated, and they could be upset if it wasn’t. The task is too big for the PCC. How could it realistically monitor all of the British press, including national and regional newspapers and magazines? 

There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy has been violated, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some may have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story that they want to keep from the press, and they know that complaining could make it public. In this way, the PCC could become an enemy.

One British comedian faced problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He did not complain then, nor did he complain later when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, claiming they thought it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he would have a sense of humor about it. This fear is understandable. People believe they will become targets again if they challenge the tabloids. It is difficult to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

**Simplified Text:**

Many college graduates receive advice when starting their first job. This article focuses on what to consider when moving to a second job. We are not talking about those who are looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those who leave a job they don’t like after a few weeks. Instead, we will discuss how to choose a second job that matches your career goals after gaining some experience and skills.

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, aim for higher positions, or explore a wider field. Whatever you choose, it is important to select your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next position. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop new skills, and give you more responsibilities.

If you want to travel, now might be a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you return and then find your second job. Employers will appreciate that you have satisfied your desire to travel and are less likely to leave again.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after graduating from St. Aldate's College working for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.

Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Although her job title is the same, her responsibilities have changed. She has moved from mainly typing and answering phones to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also answers questions from company chairmen and people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

**Text: 'What is the Secret of Confident People?'**

Confident people may seem like they were born that way, but most will say it is a skill they learned over time. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. At about twenty-five, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I was nervous but surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I felt very anxious, but my confidence grew over time, and I became more outgoing. Looking back, working at the school changed my life and helped me in many other areas.

**B. Michaela**  
My journey began four years ago when my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became a bit too aggressive. I thought that was what being confident meant, but I learned that true confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel unconfident, so I often talk to myself to push those fears away.

**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but the calmer I seem, the more scared I actually am. I had to learn to look confident because it is very important in TV. Interviewing people has shown me that many of us feel tense in important situations, but we feel better when we talk to friendly people. My mother gave me great advice when I was a teenager worrying about my clothes: 'Who is looking at you? Everyone is too busy worrying about themselves.' I remember this often. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. When I took my driving test, I was very nervous, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.

**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from your mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked in the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. You must accept yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers many training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. They also encourage us to set realistic goals. It is helpful to see that you are achieving something instead of trying to do everything at once and ending up with nothing.

**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up, even when I disagreed. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I first worked in politics, I had never spoken in public and would shake with nerves. I told myself, 'Don’t be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down a few notes to refer to, like a comfort blanket! I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

**Text: Visit to Malaysia**

Paul Forster visits a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his broken kite. "You should keep it," he said, "it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it... and I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, looking at Malaysia's biggest kite festival. 

In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites, and a line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the sky like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each competitor had entered four different kite designs, which would be judged on decoration, stability in the air, and flying ability. 

"Flying kites isn't very hard," Adnan said, "but making them takes real skill. Come to my house, and I'll show you how to do it." This was one of five invitations I received that day, and I decided to accept. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, shiny room. As night fell, he asked me to come back the next day to start fixing his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through beautiful mountains covered in thick rainforest. 

I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that pointed up a path into the forest, saying: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started, it would have been good to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He took care of a tent kitchen and a few bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects crawling under my thin mattress. 

The night was completely dark, filled with different sounds. A nearby waterfall roared, and many creatures moved and made noise. In the morning, I saw a stunning view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the treetops. Moments later, I was soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the big drops. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill. 

In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But their questions were friendly. While Kelantan is famous for its kites, I will always remember it for the kindness of its people.

**Text: What Kind of Shopper Are You?**

We all go shopping, whether we like it or not. But there are different types of shoppers. Do you know what type you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

A. **Melanie, 22, Dancer**  
I love shopping! I can't spend enough money. When I have cash, I go shopping and feel happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We are both addicted to shopping!

B. **Brenda, 40, Office Manager**  
I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but I don’t enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and don’t tell my husband the real price.

C. **Juliet, 28, Personnel Manager**  
I only shop for what I need. I really dislike shopping and only go when I have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won’t settle for anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather be doing something else.

D. **Anita, 35, TV Producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to get in and out quickly. However, I do have some clothes in my wardrobe that I regret buying, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes.

E. **Lizzie, 41, Secretary**  
I really dislike shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I like, and the shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food shopping, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly.

F. **Lisa, 22, Actress**  
I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually go with a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it.

G. **Suki, 26, Art Gallery Assistant**  
I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy much. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often regret spending too much money.

H. **Ann-Marie, 29, Nursery Worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have a good idea of what I want and don’t buy things right away. I like to check other shops to find better deals, which takes me a long time.

I. **Linda, 32, Restaurant Manager**  
I don’t like shopping, maybe because I work in the city center and the shops don’t interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I go but don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t mind making mistakes rather than spending a lot of time in shops.

**NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE**

The Open University offers degrees just like other universities. The difference is that you can study while continuing to work. This can help you explore many new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the excitement of learning new things. You will also meet many different people. Your degree may lead to new job opportunities.

At the Open University, you do not attend lectures in person. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. If you want, you can go to one class a month at an Open University center. There are exams to take, just like at any university. 

If you want to learn more, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about surprises. Free quiz sheets can be picked up at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will be guided to 14 surprising paintings and will answer different questions about them. The quiz sheets will be available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery now has a beautiful still life painting by the Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778. It is common for artists to date their work in two years because they wait for certain flowers to bloom in different seasons. This painting was kindly given to the Gallery by Miss Violet Churchman in memory of her sister, Ida Nancy. It is now displayed in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" opened in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery has recently acquired works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu, who are the main focus of the exhibition. They are joined by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists who worked in Spain during this period: Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition will be open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures related to the special exhibition continues every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work, and on 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will speak about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant has improved and expanded its services. With new kitchens, the restaurant now offers a wide variety of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11:00 am and 3:00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and showcase a wide range of important European art from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

**Text: Little Chefs**

For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't very excited at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home."

**Text: Outdoor Centre Fees**

The fees for the Outdoor Centre are for a car with four people. If you have more than four people, each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organization that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. If you are coming with a group, please let the centre know in advance.

**Windsurfing - One-day Course**

We offer beginner windsurfing courses on Saturdays and Sundays when the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. We have boards with small sails for beginners. The course fee is £32.50, which includes all the equipment.

**One-day Adventure Course**

This is a great chance for you to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is designed to introduce outdoor activities to adults in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have any previous experience. All you need is an interest in the activities. The course fee is £22.50.

**Play Park**

The Play Park is for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best parks of its kind in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

**Group Day and Residential Courses**

We also offer day and weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups often visit us. There are three large rooms with twelve beds in each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (with a minimum of 12).

**Summer Adventure Holidays (for ages 8-14)**

Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We ensure that all children participate in activities that are suitable for their age and physical abilities. For this program, children must be able to swim 25 meters and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun and interesting hobby. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a passion that can last a lifetime. 

Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals. Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. 

As a member of the club, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: 
1. We can send you a complete set of stamps in an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. If you prefer, we can send you individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too! A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group of friends joins together, you can get a discount. This is great value for money! 

When you join, the club sends you a Starter Pack for free. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide with tips on how to add to your collection and useful addresses of shops that sell stamps. 

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes. It also gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members from around the world. 

Why not start an adventure that will bring you joy for years? You will spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for rare ones that are waiting to be found. 

Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and enjoy the fun of stamp collecting! To join, just fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days after we receive your application.

**MONEY**

What is money? The pound, the dollar, and the franc are types of money, similar to how a gram or a kilometre measures weight or distance. The main difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can be used to buy a book, a large bag of sweets, or a few cinema tickets. However, the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to produce.

Thousands of years ago, people did not have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for honey from Mr. Hive. This was a simple exchange between two people who each had something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own forms of money, called 'currencies', to make trading easier. Eventually, different currencies started to connect, which is why today we all use a national currency.

**Text: Write a Winning Story!**

You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky winners will receive £100 each. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges include Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a television reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective fiction was very popular, but the winner wrote a love story.

You can write about anything you like, but here are some tips to help you:

1. **Write About What You Know**: This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many stories were about love, family, and friendship problems. Try to make ordinary situations interesting so that people want to read them.

2. **Get Your Facts Right**: Make sure your descriptions are accurate. If you write about a town or how a jet engine works, be sure you have the correct information.

3. **Hold the Reader's Attention**: Start your story in an interesting way and end it with a surprise. A weak ending can ruin a good story. Develop your story carefully and think of something unusual for the ending.

4. **Think About the Characters**: Make your characters feel real by using good words to describe them.

Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, typed, double-spaced, and printed on one side of each page. We cannot accept stories sent by fax or email, even if you are close to the deadline. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions.

You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country. This is a new rule based on popular request. Your story must not have been published in any form, such as on radio or TV, anywhere in the world.

You need to pay a fee of £5 to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.

**THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST**

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many centuries, she was the only woman scientist recognized in history. Her father was the director of Alexandria University, and he ensured that she received the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia returned to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her understanding of new ideas. Although we do not have her books, we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and created several scientific tools to assist her work. During her time, many rulers were afraid of science, and those involved in it were often in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.

**Text: Grass**

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different types of grass, and they can be found in every part of the earth. Grass is the only type of flowering plant that can grow in very cold places like the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals rely on grass in some way.

One interesting fact about grass is that it grows back quickly after being cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, there is always fresh grass available because it starts to grow again.

Text: Kal Kaur Rai, the Young Achiever of the Year, has always loved fashion. She recently won this title at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who run a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university.

After finishing university, Kal moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to many industry events but could not afford the designer clothes she wanted. To solve this, she started making skirts and tops for herself. When her friends saw her creations, they asked her to make clothes for them too. 

Kal then found a small shop in London that agreed to sell her designs. The clothes were very popular, and none of them were returned. This success encouraged her to leave her job in advertising, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own women's clothing brand. Her parents were supportive of her decision, which made her very happy.

Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates outfits for pop stars, and she gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels grateful for her success, saying, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**Sunningdale Hotel**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has provided great service for guests from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here. The hotel is located on a main road that leads to the town center. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the center of town, and many buses stop outside the hotel. Guests should avoid buses with a blue sign that says "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 comfortable, heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. Guests who stay for a long time must pay for their rooms weekly in advance, and they need to give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests are given priority for rooms. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. **Text: Tom Cruise**

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. However, his life has not always been easy. As a young boy, Tom was shy and found it hard to make friends, but he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, the film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each film. Today, Tom still acts in movies and remains very popular with his many fans around the world.

Text: 'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. He gave her some milk and started to ask questions. He called his last customers, but they had not lost a cat. Since it was getting late, he took Bo home for the night and the next morning took her to an animal hospital. Bo's owner had also been looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.'

**Simplified Text:**

Mark Ottaway took a train journey from Darwin, in northern Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train travels across Australia, from the warm northern coast through long stretches of desert to the cooler Southern Ocean. It is often called the "famous Ghan," but it is known for being late. 

The idea of a train link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line that went from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, there were often floods that made it hard for trains to run. A new line was finished just a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. It has few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good. The railway was originally made to transport goods, not passengers. It was believed that sending goods from Europe to southern Australia through Darwin and the train would save time and money compared to shipping around the continent. 

It is rare to complete a transcontinental railway, and the Ghan claims to be the first north-south railway in the world. As I waited to get on the Ghan, I noticed that everyone was excited about the trip. Most of my fellow travelers were older Australians who were eager to board. Our first stop was Katherine, where the Ghan stayed for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I joined a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. 

From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey there. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting; there is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But on the third day, at dawn, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was ending, and even though the train did not meet all the promises in the advertisements, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

**Climbing to the Top of Britain**

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt shares his experience of climbing Ben Nevis for the first time.

"It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We chose a route up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is six hundred metres high, probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are large bowls cut into the mountain halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes on Ben Nevis because the snow can be very hard, making it feel like walking on ice. 

Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment, including lights to attract attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge.

The path quickly became steep, and my legs felt heavy. I was the weakest member of the group, so I had to take more breaks. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I arrived, they would start climbing again. I promised myself that I would train better before my next climb.

After climbing 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only a metre and a half wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we finally reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometres away. However, we were not so lucky because a mist had come down.

Getting back down to camp can be just as hard as going up. You need to read a map well; a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt I really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top."

**Anna's New School**

This week has been very exciting because we have moved into our new school building! It is an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like in our old school, but this one is also designed to be environmentally friendly. The school took many months to build, and we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it also meant that some nice open space was lost. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because it rained a lot. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are much bigger than the ones in our old school next door, which was very old. We also share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms that we are looking forward to using when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice that there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from everyone inside - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound in, so when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that the school roof has a tree on it! The builders put it there after finishing the roof because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for the lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We went with our teacher to see it yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that you can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, some parts are still being finished. For example, we are putting on a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready by next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster now that we are here!

**Text: No Title**

A month ago, I never thought that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place where we stayed was not great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air.

On Saturday morning, we met the other ten members of our group. Cameron came with his friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with their friend Amanda. We all came from different places and did not know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we were not sure how.

Half of us went caving in the morning, while the others went rock climbing. We switched activities at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out—covered in mud but happy and excited about what we had done.

**Letter to the Newport Evening News**

On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn’t know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I felt very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried.

A young man saw me and asked what was wrong. I told him what happened. He kindly gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver about my handbag, he said I could keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they had found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me.

I was amazed to get my handbag back with everything inside still there. I want to thank everyone who helped me that day. I really appreciate their kindness and honesty.

Mrs. B. James, Newport

**Sharks**

Sharks are some of the most frightening animals in our oceans. They are very good at finding food underwater because they can see well and feel movement through special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.

Although sharks are similar to other fish in some ways, their bodies are different. For example, most sharks must swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they hardly ever sleep. Also, if sharks are turned upside down, they can stop moving completely. This is a useful technique for researchers who need to study sharks. It helps them learn more about these interesting creatures.
