**Text: Joining the Kirov Ballet**

My name is Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. On my first day of ballet class, I felt nervous because I didn’t know anyone. Everyone came over to ask me questions in Russian. I tried to respond in Russian, and then they switched to English, so we could talk. Now, six months later, everyone is very friendly, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers well.

For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mom stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late one night to talk to her because I was feeling lonely. The classes in Russia are much harder than those in my ballet school in England, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This helps me meet the school’s high standards.

In the evenings, I like to watch my favorite movies on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before they finish. Now that I have settled in, I feel at home here. I enjoy walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the locals said that was mild for that time of year! At least my room is warm and cozy.

Right now, we are getting ready for a new production, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I plan to enter. I feel very lucky to be here.

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, the Arctic was a popular place to visit in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. However, in winter, the few people living there enjoyed the snow and ice by themselves. By the end of the 1980s, people began to see the dark and cold winter as a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an exhibition in a specially built igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi, located on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors to the area. One night, a group of foreign guests decided to sleep in Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was created. Today, it is famous around the world.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from different countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As each part is finished, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is completed in December, and each week after that, a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is fully completed. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside using natural winter materials, the finishing date can change depending on the weather.

In spring, as the weather gets warmer, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is never colder than -5 to -8 degrees Celsius, no matter how cold it is outside. Guests receive winter clothes like warm overalls, hats, and gloves as part of their stay. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, scarves, and plenty of woollen socks. They should choose shoes that are larger than usual to fit the thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, woollen socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items along with your booking, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is located in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

**Text: Shopping for Furniture**

A report by Dave Worthington

Homestyle, a new furniture shop, had to close shortly after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's regular hours will be from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening.

A police officer who was called to the shop said: "The police knew a large crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The shop quickly became full, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was space for them. Another problem was that there was a long line of cars trying to get to the parking lot. I couldn't believe that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the shop. This blocked the road completely."

One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: "I waited in line for three hours, and I didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again."

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of the most active arts organizations in Britain.

**Society Magazines**

We produce several great magazines, including the popular *Short Story Review*. This magazine features short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, *Short Story News*, includes interviews with writers and has information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing community. You can find articles from recent issues on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We organize the National Short Story Competition, which is the largest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and older, and stories on any topic are welcome. Short stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society can enter for free, while non-members must pay a fee of £5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will receive a contract to publish their own collection of short stories.

**Education**

For nearly thirty years, the Society has worked with schools, helping children and teachers with new ideas and building confidence in writing. One of our current projects is the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is for writers aged 11-18. All winners receive book prizes and are invited to a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is a relaxed and stylish place with freshly cooked vegetarian food, great coffee, and cold drinks. It is perfect for reading the Society's magazines. The Cafe also hosts monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Members receive discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world, and anyone aged 18 or older can join. If you want to become a member of The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

**Text: Free-diving in the Caribbean**

Tanya Streeter is a free-diver who holds four world records in this sport. Free-diving is when people dive deep into the ocean using only one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya made history by becoming the first person to dive 120 meters deep while holding her breath and then swim back up without any help. A year earlier, she had dived deeper but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, making her the first woman to break a world record previously held by a man.

During her dive, a team of fourteen safety divers watched her from different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents that have happened, but Tanya believes that safety and training are very important. Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya keeps a consistent training schedule. Two-thirds of her training is done in the gym, while the rest is split between the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to stay fit.

When she practices diving, Tanya usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, taking a rest day between each dive. It is important for her not to get tired, as this could affect her performance. When she is not training, Tanya often makes public appearances to promote sports products and supports environmental organizations through research and films.

Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman, where she loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. She feels that her life now is like living her childhood dreams. Because she is famous in some countries, she believes people listen to her when she talks about environmental issues. Looking to the future, Tanya, who is now in her thirties, plans to continue breaking her own world records. She started free-diving at the age of twenty-five and wants to keep competing for many more years.

**CARTOON FILMS**

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the screen. New ideas and advanced computer programs are making cartoons exciting for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, many in the film industry thought cartoons were only for children. However, a few directors had original ideas that showed cartoons could be fun for both adults and children. 

Not every cartoon film was successful. For example, *The Black Cauldron* did not do well because it was too scary for children and too silly for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started to make a lot of money again.

**Text: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role**

"I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming *The Finnegans*. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother used to say I was just like Polly Finnegan, and I always dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me to say they were planning to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised at first, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part.

Filming started a week after university began, so I asked for permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned to university, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on the essays I had missed. I didn’t tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was exciting. It was an amazing experience, and I feel very lucky.

After university, I definitely want to make acting my career. I am not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I have tried for other TV roles, but I haven’t received any offers yet. I’m not sure how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn’t know what to do next. Since then, I have acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven’t been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I am going to Greece for the summer with friends."

**Text:**

When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough money to feed my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a fast-growing international company. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is shared in this book. I believe we have important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our values.

This is not just a typical business book or a story about my life. The main message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can help others. In both business and life, I want to have fun, feel like I am part of a family, and be excited by new experiences. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way.

Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I hope there are no limits to our 'family' and to what we can achieve. I find this thought exciting, and I hope you do too.

**A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River**

Jules Verne operates a 'hotel ship' on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May can accommodate 160 guests in double cabins, all with outside views and private bathrooms. On the ship, which has air-conditioning, you will find a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

**Itinerary**

**Day 1:** You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and arrive in Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will spend the night.

**Day 2:** After sightseeing in Oporto in the morning, you will return to the ship and sail to Entre-os-Rios. This part of the journey takes four hours.

**Day 3:** You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship will stop at Peso da Regua, known for its port wine. At dinner, you can enjoy delicious local food and drink.

**Day 4:** After breakfast, you will travel by bus to the ancient town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum that used to be a palace. The museum has a great collection of paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. After the visit, you will return to the ship and sail to Tua.

**Day 5:** The Douro River becomes very narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you may take a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach, enjoying the sights along the way.

**Day 6:** In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for one of the best views in the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take the Douro River Valley railway for a scenic ride to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for you.

**Day 7:** You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will sail down the river to Oporto and spend the night on board.

**Day 8:** You will arrive in Oporto with enough time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.

**HONEY**

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. 

In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. The ancient Egyptians valued honey so much that they used it as payment. Today, honey is produced and eaten all over the world. Research shows that honey can help reduce tiredness and improve athletic performance. However, honey is not just food; it can also be used for sore throats and is found in many skin and hair-care products.

**Text: Norwich**

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a region in Britain, and has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it an important center for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and to govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second city of England. It continued to grow for the next 300 years, becoming wealthy and famous for having many churches and pubs. Nowadays, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich. With a growing student population and its success as a modern commercial center (it is the largest center for insurance services outside London), Norwich now offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team known as 'The Canaries', which wears green and yellow.

One of the city's recent developments is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich dealt with a large hole in the city while builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to create a park on the roof of the Mall, complete with water pools and many trees. The local people are happy that the old open market still exists in the city center, next to the new shopping center. Both areas continue to thrive, showing that Norwich has successfully combined the old and the new.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about twelve hot-air balloons taking off from a parking lot in the city. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from more than a third of the countries in the world are expected to participate at its current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The pilots communicate with each other using radios, and they all light up the burners of their balloons at the same time. This event is called a "balloon glow," and it is a great chance to take amazing photographs. To see the "glows," you should arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am, as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready for take-off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, with some shaped like animals or cartoon characters, as well as popular products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will enjoy it too. 

In the afternoon, you can even take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies that offer rides. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, which is the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a local wind pattern that creates perfect conditions for balloon flying. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentler winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are important. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, don’t forget your camera. If you use film instead of digital photography, make sure to bring high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

**The Eden Project**

The Eden Project, located in the south-west of England, is one of the most popular tourist attractions in the UK. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere represents a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the connection between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many everyday products come from plants, such as wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. More than 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold it is outside, computer-controlled heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always humid because of a large waterfall. Another zone mimics the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone in the future.

**Text: No Title**

Some people have said they do not like this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I do not understand why. Getting 500 pages of original writing of this quality for £6.99 is quite impressive, right? Most of the book is made up of fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, many lesser-known writers have written mainly about food. I recommend you avoid reading Jane Harris's "Those Nails" right after eating, as it has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset you! 

The collection also features great work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels that are still being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about her own life. This is an outstanding collection, and I am excited to see what next year's edition will bring!

**Text:**

"The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when children are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, usually teaches children who are three or four years old, but she has also accepted some eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old friends.

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts one hour, taking place every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be involved in their children's learning.

From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not start reading music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how they play and how they read music. Margaret explains that her teaching method is not meant to create great violinists. She often suggests that students who do very well should leave and learn the violin using more traditional methods.

**Moonshine**

The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to their previous CD, "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD: Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the new drummer. 

From the first song, which is a dance tune, it is clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance track and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but either of them could easily become a hit single because they are excellent. 

Singer Rob Letchford has a chance to show his talent, hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded these songs before he had throat problems, which caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets does not need to worry, as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob has recovered.)

On this CD, Moonshine demonstrates that they can create great music in different styles, from the slow songs we know to the upbeat ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that they placed their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as strong. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and will bring more success to the band.

**Text: San Francisco**

San Francisco is located on the northern California coast. The first Europeans to find this area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, but it was discovered by land, not by sea. 

In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The wealthiest people were those who owned banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. 

Today, many tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Some even take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to visit the old prison.

**SAMUEL PEPYS**

The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting view of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about important events of that time, such as diseases, an enemy navy coming up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also shares personal stories, including his mistakes—like often falling asleep in church or looking at pretty girls. He talks about his home life, including arguments with his wife and how they made up, as well as his worries about her health. Besides reading, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and fun. Pepys was a busy man with many important jobs; he was a Member of Parliament and the President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.

**The History of Shoes**

In the past, people did not think much about whether shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles to keep warm. Today, we still use leather, but we also have shoes made from materials like silk, plastic, and cotton, depending on current fashion trends. 

It was only about 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes for each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry produce many more shoes at lower prices, making them available to more people.

**Text:**

When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women get into running, to show them how enjoyable it can be and to help them feel confident. So, I started a running club for women in my area. I was frustrated with many race organisers who complain about not having enough women in the sport but do not provide separate changing rooms for them.

I put up posters, and 40 women of different ages and fitness levels joined. Most of them were interested in losing weight, but I don’t think they had thought much about running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn’t see it as a chance to chat and smile while running in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned about diet and staying fit from other runners. I wanted to support women in running, and it has been a joy to see their progress, almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state in the USA. Many people moved there to try to get rich. New towns were built quickly, including one called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska.

In the summer, supplies could be brought to these towns by boat. However, in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it hard to reach them. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog teams pulling sleds. They delivered mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took a team of dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could sleep and eat.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced boats and dog teams as the main transport. However, in 1925, the dogs became famous again when a disease called diphtheria struck the city of Nome. The medicine needed to cure the disease was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were new, and no one was sure if they could fly in the cold. The only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away at that time. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine instead.

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty dog teams just six days to complete the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian searching for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to find the way through the heavy snow, and Togo proved to be a great guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Saito. At one point, Balto, another dog, refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous journey in 1925. This race is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

**Sweden's Ice Hotel**

The village of Jukkasjarvi is located in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, around 6,000 tourists visit each year to see one of the most unique hotels in Europe. In this hotel, everything is made of ice, including the rooms where you can eat, drink, and sleep. You can even have a wedding there! The bar is also made of ice, so it is not a good idea to put hot drinks on it. 

The bedrooms are kept at about -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to keep warm. If needed, they can also get suitable outdoor clothing. The hotel lasts for only six months because it melts in the summer, and every winter, it is rebuilt. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

**Maria Mutola**

In 1988, Maria Mutola was playing football as the only girl on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was published in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported other African athletes, learned about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her kicking a ball outside the football club. He quickly realized that she was very fast.

"He talked to me about athletics. I didn’t understand what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt." Jose spoke to her parents and convinced them that she could be successful, which would help their family. They agreed to let him take her away to train.

In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She said, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs and spends most of the year happily living in South Africa with her mother.

**The Skywalk**

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Many people visit Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and it is even better because of the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1,219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform made of glass, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. The Skywalk opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of visitors have enjoyed it. To protect the glass, you must wear special covers over your shoes. Walking on the Skywalk feels like flying high in the air, like a bird.

**THE ROCKIES**

The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the Northwest but are also found a few hundred miles from the center in the southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are still very beautiful. There are many roads that go through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. 

You can start your journey from Vancouver, which is one of the most beautiful cities in Canada. This city is located near the water and the mountains, allowing people to ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day for the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still an exciting adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but you will see some of the best views at night.

**Text: ZOOS**

People have kept animals in zoos for over 3,000 years. The first big zoo was called the Gardens of Intelligence, opened by the rulers of China. In the past, animals in zoos were trained to perform for visitors, but this is no longer done. Now, the main purpose of zoos is to let people see animals behaving naturally.

Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with zoos. Supporters of zoos believe they help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close. They think these experiences would not be possible without zoos.

On the other hand, some people do not like zoos. They believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals may live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.

**JAZZ**  
By Katie Atkins, aged 14  

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like my band to bright T-shirts. We didn’t look like professional adult bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of our playing was amazing, especially since we are all so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played!  

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets accepted—only about half of the students. However, anyone who is eager to play can go to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I have been to a couple and learned a lot.  

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it’s because pop music isn’t challenging enough for serious music lovers like me. I find jazz exciting because it feels both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel connected to its history, as you play on stage like great jazz performers did before you. My school is very lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn’t get far with our music!

**Text: Watering the Desert**

In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, it does not rain often. When it does rain, the city's water pipes cannot handle the sudden floods, causing the streets to become like rivers. Many winters have been dry recently, so when it rains, the local people are very happy. 

The parks and gardens in Marrakesh do not rely on rain; instead, they get water from a system of underground channels that were built in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year round. Places that are mostly dry but receive water this way are called oases.

If you travel south from Marrakesh, you will reach Skoura. In Skoura, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels, and people use these squares to grow food. The snow-covered Atlas mountains in winter create a beautiful view.

**Text: Gareth Ellis**

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old and the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. Kath says, "People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three."

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time jobs in the circus. They both found jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away.

Kath explains, "I can't say it was easy. There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths."

Gareth shares, "People ask about my education, but from the start, someone has always come to teach me wherever we go. I use the same books as my classmates at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind."

What about the future? Kath says, "It was a difficult decision, but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? He says, "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day, maybe Bippo's circus."

**Eight-eighteen News**

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to important national and local newspapers, magazines, television, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website.

We have three centers across the country where young people can meet other members and join projects. We plan to open more centers in the future. Since we started in 1994, when we were called 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie is one of them. She says: "I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities they had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to do stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I turned 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee on a major news website, checking articles before they are published."

**Get Involved at Every Level**

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will receive training and participate in monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share their skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members who are 12 years old and older. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside of Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website! Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short summer in Antarctica, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, on a Boeing 747. These flights take you over Antarctica and back. The exact dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be moved to a different date if needed.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**  
The average flight lasts 12 hours. About four hours into the flight, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have worked in Antarctica will talk about the environment and history, and they will answer your questions. There is also a camera next to the pilot that shows a view from the cockpit throughout the flight.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**  
All passengers receive two boarding passes. At the halfway point of the flight, you will be asked to move to the seat shown on your second boarding pass. Business and first-class passengers will have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to a window for the other half. Economy passengers will have either a window seat or a seat next to a window for half of the flight and an end-of-row seat for the other half. While flying over Antarctica, we encourage passengers to get up and move around the plane so everyone can enjoy the views. The pilot will fly in long 'figure 8s' over interesting places to give everyone a good view from both sides of the plane.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**  
We have 17 different flight plans approved. On the morning of the flight, the captain will check the satellite images of the clouds and choose the direction that offers the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**  
Most wildlife in Antarctica lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we cannot see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica for environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**  
Yes! You can bring all types of cameras. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

**Text: Little Chefs**

For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course, where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, "I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down to share the food we've made." 

Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. She says, "I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. My mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. At first, I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't very interested. But now, I'm really glad I decided to come." 

Their teacher, Philippe, says, "It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, even if the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will have the skills to make food for themselves when they leave home."

**Winter Driving**

Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can appear suddenly over a hill. Ice may be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control of your car. A car coming towards you might slide across the road unexpectedly.

**Rule Number One** for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick or sudden movements can make it hard to control your car. When you turn the wheel, brake, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive carefully so you don’t spill it.

**Rule Number Two** is to pay attention to what could happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid problems.

**Craigie Aitchison**

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London to study law but decided to go to art school instead. At art school, he found the traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art, and he became interested in early Italian artists, which can be seen in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the bright light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. 

To do this, he painted colors thinly, layering them from light to dark, but he admits he is never sure what the final result will be. He says, "It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top." Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it seem easy. He believes, "Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what you put the colors next to."

Unlike some artists, he does not make drawings before starting a painting because he thinks that if he did, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers to work with models who do not ask to see their pictures while he is painting. He says, "If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it."

Since moving to London, he has not felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He claims he is not interested in following any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still inspires young British painters.

**Text: 'Rock Band'**

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. Ben argued, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. We said, "Okay, but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the beginning. Since drums are hard to move, Ben's band members started coming to our house with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, our house shakes with their music and singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band practices, my husband and I go for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music can sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skills; after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager. They do play regularly in local clubs for young people.

Our main worry is that they might not spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, but this hasn't happened yet. I always remind Ben how important his studies are. One thing is certain: Ben was right; playing music has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.

**Text: Atlantic College**

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private college in Wales. This college offers students important experiences outside the classroom, along with the chance to study for their exams. The students, aged 16 to 18 and from all over the world, study in the morning. In the afternoon, they participate in useful activities, such as helping on a farm, caring for people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are £20,000 for two years, many students receive financial support. About a quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands, said, "I really admire the college for encouraging international understanding among young people. You learn to live with and respect others, even those you may not like. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed that I argued much less with my sister."

In summary, Atlantic College provides an excellent education with methods that really work.

**Text: Being an Older Student**

At 32 years old, I have just completed my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I earned a decent salary, but I felt bored because my job did not challenge me. I became unhappy thinking that I was stuck in that job. I envied the students at the local university who seemed happy, carefree, and excited about their future. 

Now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel distant from the professors because, even though we are the same age, I know much less than they do. However, I am grateful for this chance to study because I understand that having a qualification is important for getting a good job. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends studying rather than going out to parties. 

There are also typical student benefits, like long holidays and discounts for theaters and cinemas. I often worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this age has been a smart decision.

**Henry Ford**

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong but light steel, he created affordable cars for regular people. In 1908, he produced the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant fewer choices. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

**Rebecca Stevens**

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before this achievement, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is very difficult. "You must carry everything on your back," she said. "You can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!"

When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. Suddenly, she became famous. Now, she has written a book about her journey, and people often ask her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science program on television. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!

Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday. 

Love,

**Text: CANADA GEESE**

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to find warmer weather. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. 

Last spring, a man named Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. These young birds had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds will not know how to fly south in the autumn." Bill had a small plane, so he decided to teach the geese to follow him. 

All summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn arrived and the weather got cold, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him the whole way. 

After reaching Virginia, Bill left the geese there and returned home. This spring, he waited for the birds to come back, but they did not arrive. So, Bill flew back to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but could not find them. When he returned home, he was surprised to see the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without his help!

**ESTHER'S STORY**

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther decided to use her aunt's money to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly made back her aunt's £500.

At first, Esther's parents did not want her to spend her time making jam. They thought she should study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther did not listen to them and continued making jam. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. Then, she started making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked.

After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were proud of her. She made many types of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she needed to hire some people to help her.

**Corryvale Farm**

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler raise cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the wool from the sheep to keep them cool.

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters from the wool and tried to sell them at local markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people were not interested in buying sweaters. Instead, she decided to make socks. Everyone loved the socks because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This is how Jenny's business began.

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers. To keep up with the demand, she started sending the wool to a factory, where machines now make all the socks. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different types of socks for walkers, athletes, and skiers. Jenny is especially busy during Christmas because Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In her office, she has many letters from happy customers around the world.

**Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON'**

Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also mentioned that 67% of burglaries occur when people leave their homes and forget to lock a door or a window. 

Inspector Saunders explained that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home during that time. However, winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it gets dark, making it hard for them to be seen. Many houses are empty during this time because people are still at work.

Inspector Saunders suggested that it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This can help keep burglars away. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over each other's houses when someone is not home and to call the police if they notice anything unusual. 

"We will also give you advice on how to make your house safe," Inspector Saunders said. "This kind of help is free."

**The History of Farming**

Before farming started, people searched in the forest for plants and fruits to eat. This meant they had to move around a lot to find food. However, about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and over time, their villages grew larger. Some villagers could then do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers provided food for everyone. 

However, farming was hard, especially when the weather was bad, and some people did not have enough food. Today, farmers can produce more food, and it can travel thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.

**Working for an Airline**

Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she became a manager. Here is what she said about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time in the air. I teach flight attendants and help them with any problems. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer and then I talk with some of the flight attendants. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That is my favorite part of the job, but I also enjoy office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I want to do is eat something and then go to bed! I don’t earn a lot of money, but I am happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

I am happy to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I felt sad when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even harder. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love, Sophie

The Weather People study the weather for many reasons, and it is important for many jobs. For instance, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers looked at the sky, animals, and flowers to understand the weather better. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather updates on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. For example, they say that if the sky is red in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that if cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Text: 'A great idea! Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from the same small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the last few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who has trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing sounds than by reading. His brother wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make this computer game, and now it is ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be sold around the world. Many schools are interested in buying it.'

**How Does the Irish Pop Group 'Boyzone' Live a Healthy Life?**

Sleeping well is very important. When I can go home to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, I find it hard to sleep at night after a concert because my mind is full of music. 

Sport is also important. Before I had a car accident, I went to the sports center for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups each day. I don’t drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat healthy food. I also drink a lot of water because it is good for your health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don’t always drink that much.

People shouldn’t work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I like to listen to music or watch TV. It is good to relax sometimes. I don’t feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now, I eat many healthy foods like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!

**Text: Bollywood**

Bollywood is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It produces almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, which is much more than the USA. This makes it the largest film industry in the world. 

Most Indians enjoy watching films more than any other leisure activity, and about ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films often tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of these films. Indian films are also popular outside of India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries.

Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they earn less money. This is why most Bollywood films cost around $2 million to make, while Hollywood films usually cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work hard, but they often have short careers. Amitabh Bachchan, who many consider India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in more than 140 films over a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson

I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life here. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I like Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, is starting college here soon, so it will be another four years before we go back.

I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to discuss my new book. Most writers do not enjoy this; they do not like traveling around the country to promote their book. However, I enjoy it. I like visiting new places and meeting many people. This experience is very different from my life in the United States when I am writing. In England, people drove me in big cars, and I stayed in nice hotels. It was great because I did not have to pay any bills. Everyone was friendly to me, and it was a lot of fun.'

**Schnauzer Dogs**

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England more than 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is newer to the country. The name "Giant" is fitting because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs to be cut regularly. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because they are very smart. Schnauzers make great family pets. They are friendly and good with young children.

**The Ruwenzori Mountains**

Mary Daniels is a student from England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns.

"It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food," said Mary. "It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world."

Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best experience she has ever had. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. **Text: The History of Horse Racing**

Horse racing has been an important sport for a long time. It began in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing started in the 12th century when Arab horses were brought to Europe. 

At first, races were long and only involved two horses. However, in the early 18th century, this changed. Races became shorter and included several horses competing against each other. 

Today, horse racing is one of the most-watched sports in the USA, second only to baseball. It is also very popular in many other countries.

Text: 'World traveler Nick Barlow enjoys his job. He is a British actor who travels around the world making TV shows. "People are friendly to me wherever I go, and when I return home, I remember all the amazing experiences I had in each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still a few trips he wants to take. "I would love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he adds. 

On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring the cameras and other equipment needed to make the show. Nick doesn’t pack many personal items, just a few shirts and pants, but he always makes sure to bring some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling for work. She has many friends and keeps herself busy. When he returns, she enjoys listening to his travel stories. 

However, sometimes there are challenges. When he was in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick found out that his wife was sick in the hospital. "I felt awful because I couldn’t help her, but she didn’t want me to come home. I was so relieved when I heard she was better."

**Text: Parrots**

You may have seen parrots, which are beautiful birds with bright colors and long tails. They live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. Parrots usually live in large groups and enjoy eating fruit, which can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet that help them climb and hold food. Some of the largest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very loud, but they are also smart and can learn to talk easily. Some zoos have shows where you can watch parrots perform tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER

Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about many of the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old.

When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend a lot of money on clothes and CDs. Instead, he used his money to visit France and eat at good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty!

So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it is expensive to start your own restaurant and it is much harder to cook for fifty people than to cook for your family, but he is sure he has made the right choice.'

**Text: John Pickering**

In a small town in central England, John Pickering cuts the grass and waters the flowers in a park. Last week, he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television because he is currently the number one singer in Japan. A few months ago, John visited Japan to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on his radio show. Many young people called the radio station to ask for his songs to be played again. 

John, who goes by the name Jon Otis when he sings in Japan, plans to continue working in the park in England. He is not sure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know that he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

**Text: Line Dancing**

Many people in Britain have started a new hobby called line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this fun activity. 

"Line dancing is easy to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!" says Fiona Lever, a teacher. "You don’t need a partner because you dance in groups. It’s a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are people of all ages. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet while dancing!"

When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

**The Rhino**

There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough, and they have very little hair. A rhino stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs about 40 kilos when it is born and stays inside its mother for around fifteen months. An adult rhino can weigh over 200 kilos and may live for up to 50 years.

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are police officers everywhere, but in 1700, London had no police at all. A few old men tried to protect the city streets at night, but they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London was growing. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people stayed at home as much as they could.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop the thieves. They were like police officers and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown very large and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was created with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police officers are paid well, and those who still ride horses earn even more than the others.

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people travel to Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come to Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are filled with music and dance from morning until night. You can even see artists painting in the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists visit the Festival to watch new films, plays, and listen to music from famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding a room can be hard, so it’s a good idea to book your hotel now!'

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim under the ice. 

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Then, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. You put the line through the hole and into the water. When the fish eat the bread, you pull the line up. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet nice people here!

**Text: Madame Tussaud's Museum**

One very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. In this museum, people can see wax figures of famous individuals. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum in Paris. Marie helped him with this work.

In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was sent to prison. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

**BICYCLES**

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created about 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were quite expensive, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we see today. Over time, as bicycles became cheaper, more people started to buy them. Many began to ride bicycles to work and for leisure.

Today, cars are used more than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to cycle to work. They believe there are too many cars in city centers, making it hard to find parking.

**The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14**

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited to see the elephant show. 

We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and started to paint on its own card. The trainers sometimes gave the elephants a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, following their trainers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another showed a tree, and the third showed a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. 

We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special places where visitors can watch them.

**Text: Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats dislike water, tigers often enjoy lying in water when it is hot. 

Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups work together to hunt for food. Lions usually inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and easily track other animals. 

All cats have good eyesight, which helps them catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are only a few left in the wild. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, at speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Text: 'Victoria Jamieson is a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain. She started snowboarding at the age of 20 and has won many competitions. We spoke to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she began this sport. She said, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so it felt natural to try snowboarding. It’s easy to learn, and you can get really good in just a few months." 

We also asked her about practice. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it is so beautiful. But free-riding, which is when you do what you want outside of competitions, is the best for me." 

Finally, we asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She explained, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It’s also important to have the right clothes so you don’t get wet, especially because you will fall a lot at first!"'

**Text: Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest. It usually takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers who attempt to reach the top succeed. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start of the climb, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers find ice and snow, and the temperature can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

**Text: Otters**

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, which caused many fish and insects to die, so otters could not find enough food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.
