**Text: Buildings**

People have always built buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and concerts. We also have buildings like museums to display beautiful things. 

Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws plans to show their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from all sides, not just the top. Another well-known building is the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This interesting structure looks like a tent made of glass.

Text: "Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you go shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will turn 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is that I don't have anything to wear. I have grown so much that all my trousers are too short for me now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Please let me know. Sarika"

Text: 'The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large picture of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. No one knows exactly when the Cerne Giant was created, but many believe it was a long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

**Text: Gail Rollins**

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 metres and maybe the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in big competitions. She always smiled and laughed, and people in her city love her for this. 

Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, which is a long road race. She won with a very good time, the fastest of any British woman that year. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. However, it is not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he cannot keep up.

Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes a break from running on Sundays. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Text: Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. At the age of ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano playing. When he was fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years. After that, he returned to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two years old, and a year later, he began playing the piano. He gave his first concert when he was six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he hopes to write his own music.

**Text: Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. "My ten grandchildren don’t live nearby, but they also read my stories and tell me if they are good or bad." This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His fifth book is his favorite: *The Sheepdog*, which is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very clever; they learn quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn’t change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of places like beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the pictures are often nicer than the photos people take themselves. 

The first postcard was sent at the end of the 1800s. It had a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards included images related to current events, like accidents or visits from important people. People liked these postcards because newspapers at that time did not have pictures.

**Dinosaurs**

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died about 60 million years ago, long before people existed on Earth. We do not know exactly why they all disappeared. The closest living relatives of dinosaurs are birds. Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were more than 5,000 different kinds. Some were very small, while others were huge. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as long, but it was very strong. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.

**BEARS**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can harm a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food using their sense of smell. 

There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish-brown. 

Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Unfortunately, not many pandas live in the wild today because it is hard for them to find food.

**CROCODILES**

Crocodiles live in warm areas of the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see crocodiles in large groups. They eat many things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they can also eat larger animals or even people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles, and they all have very sharp teeth. Although they lose teeth often, they grow new ones quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. Crocodiles can live a long time; the oldest one in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

**A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL**

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. 

Over the next thirty years, airplanes changed a lot. In the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they were equipped with jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which means the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. 

Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

**The Globe Theatre**

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round and had no roof, so people could get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, which was by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. The audience ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! 

Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.

I am having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and cold. Now, the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week, we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, and purple!
